title: Australia vs USA WSDC 2017
motion: This House would require all employees to join a union at the point of employment.

argument_units.text: to debate. Please welcome Dan. Panel, for decades, corporate interests have been waging a systematic assault against unions and the rights they stand for. They lobby political parties, they produce dishonest research, they automate, they offshore, all in the pursuit of their corporate agendas. This cruel manipulation has resulted in stagnating wages, extortionate contracts,

and the loss of fundamental rights to democratic representation amongst workers. And all our war on working people is gradually being won, as seen in the surge of right-to-work legislation across the US.

Now is the time to unify the workers. Now is the time to unify the workers. Now is the time to go on the offensive. What do we stand for in this debate? Three things. Firstly, all employees are obligated to join a union at the point of their employment, meaning they pay dues, receive voting rights and are bound to collective action. Secondly, we support regulations that make unions work in the interests of their workers, like those in place in many countries in the status quo. They should be democratic, there should be laws against union corruption and embezzlement, and where possible we support workers being able to choose between multiple unions, like in the UK, where multiple teachers' unions effectively support their rights. Finally, we define large industry as any industry which contributes to a significant proportion of employment or GDP.
So for Singapore, that's electronics manufacturing. For Bali, that's tourism. For Australia, that's agriculture and mining. And for the US, that's journalism, the service industry and sports.

I'll bring you two points in substantive in my speech. Firstly, why our model is required to ensure equal democratic representation, and secondly, why our model is necessary to secure workers' rights. On to the first. Compulsory labour unions are required to ensure equal democratic representation. Democracies are premised on having an equal say in setting the terms of our collective governments. That is a principle that motivates the foundation of one person, one vote. But voting is not the only way that you have your voice heard. An important way to get a voice in the shaking of our government is through civil affiliations. For instance, when owners of corporations pay lobbyists to help them pass certain forms of legislation. Yet, in this status quo, the owners of the means of production have a disproportionately large voice in influencing politics in their civil affiliations. For every $1 spent by unions on lobbying, corporations spend $34. Workers are shackled to the businesses in their immediate area for sustenance with no ability to push against them on an individual level. The corporate fat cat votes once at the polls, twice in donation, and three times in money. By contrast, the labourer votes once every four years in a situation where the power of their vote is going down at a worrying rate. This imbalance in power is reason in and of itself to enact our model of union membership being compulsory, even if it means taking a slight hit on GDP. Why is that? Firstly, because compulsory union membership, by its nature, provides precisely the form of political representation that the status quo deprives workers of. Firstly, it enhances the ability for workers to access political donation. Unions already spend upwards of $110 million on US presidential elections. Secondly, in terms of political advocacy, when large groups of workers are unionised, they're more able to hold the left to account by injecting ideas into discourse which are politically inconvenient. For instance, the Service Employees International Union got discussion on stagnating wages, which hugely empowered their fight to increase the minimum wage to $15. Finally, we tell you in terms of political representation, unions are an incredibly effective channel to connect the minimum wage to $15. Finally, we tell you in terms of political representation, unions are an incredibly effective channel to connect the working class worker to political networks while otherwise they would be locked out. For instance, Ian Lavery probably wouldn't have gone from mining apprentice to chair of the UK Labour Party if it weren't for his access to unions. We represent the worker when for far too long they've been silenced by corporate political hegemony. Secondly, we say our model protects workers' inability to consent to going alone. Why is that? Firstly, because workers don't fully understand or know the likelihood by which they could have extortionate conditions imposed on them or be unfairly dismissed, meaning that unions would be required to defend them. Secondly, even if they knew all the risks of going alone, workers are biased towards being optimistic, that no one thinks they'll specifically be the one to be fired in a recession. And finally, under the status quo, workers are actually coerced away from being in a union, that they can be afraid that they will be discriminated against by employers on the basis of their union membership. That is not real consent. The final claim we make on this principle is that the principle of workers' free riding is abhorrent. Non-unionised workers benefit from the sacrifice of other workers, for instance to establish and protect the minimum wage. But in no way do they contribute to those fights. They don't pay dues, they don't vote, they don't take part in collective action. They steal the fruits of the labour of the union, not happy to support them. Regardless of the economic impact of our principal panel, regardless of any harm opposition pushes, the principle of democratic representation stands above it all. Because like in the status quo, the fact that one-to-one voting may not be the most efficient is not reason to abolish it. We stand by our principles. I'll take you in a second, moving on to the second piece of substantive, which is why compulsory union membership is necessary to secure workers' rights. Why should a Muslim farmer in India be forced to join a union which donates to Hindu ethno-nationalist parties? Well, the thing is, we're not supporting them doing precisely those things, right? We supported democratic representation, we supported a number of unions. In no way would that ever happen. Okay, back to the substandard. First, note the choice this opposition must offend. It's not between compulsory union membership and, well, some unions. It's between compulsory unions and none at all. Because the trend is, without compulsory membership, they are dying. Since the 1950s, there's been a 24% decline in membership, and in the private sector, that number is already below 10. And note, this is an exponential trend, which is to say that when members leave, fees go up, the risk goes up, but bargaining power goes down, meaning remaining members are even less likely to stay. The second claim we make is that unions are essential to protect workers' rights. Firstly, that's through collective bargaining safeguarding those rights. Unionised workers earn 5-10% more on average in wages, they are 28% more likely to have healthcare, and 56% more likely to have a pension. An individual cannot campaign for those things by themselves. They risk being sacked, they risk being fired. But on our side of the house, when we collectivise the entire workforce and they bargain as a block, they eliminate those risks, they safeguard their fundamental rights. Secondly, we say unions are important because they provide crucial services to the worker they otherwise wouldn't be able to access. For instance, a poor worker being able to get a lawyer in an unfair dismissal trial, or them as a group being able to police equal protection. The final claim we make is that unions are so much stronger under Weiss out of the House. That's because scale allows unions to fight more effectively. It means larger strikes and better collective bargaining, but also economies of scale in things like healthcare and insurance, which can be easily bulk-billed. Without a revitalisation of our democracy, by balancing the corporate fat cap with the worker, we jeopardise the legitimacy of our government as a whole. That is something PSY proposition was not happy to stand by, proud to propose.

And now to open the case for the opposition the table. In the United States, 93% of the workers in the industries that Proposition is talking about, elect not to join unions. We would like to know why Australia thinks that these millions of workers are all making the wrong decision, and why the government has the right to make that decision for them. They have two burdens in this round. The first is to prove that their policy benefits all unionized workers and the economy as a whole, but second, they have to prove these benefits are so overwhelmingly important as to justify a massive rights violation inherent on their side of the house. Before rebutting their case and introducing our first two substantive arguments, let's just clarify a couple things in this round. This debate is about
the comparative. It's about which side creates the best labor policy in the long term. What's our stance? We welcome declines in union membership across the world and think in today's modern

economy unions play an actively harmful role. That said, we tolerate voluntary union membership because we recognize the importance of freedom of association, something their side flouts. But make no mistake, we're not accepting the status quo as it stands. We support alternative means of effecting labor policy, namely three things. First, we think labor law should be created through recommendations by independent commissions of economists, elected officials, and representatives from labor and industry, things like India's National Commission on Labor. Second, we would prosecute multinational corporations for flouting labor standards they adhere to at home when operating in the global south. But finally, we support other means of aligning employer-employee incentives, namely supporting things like favorable tax policy for firms co-owned by their workers. All of these are more appropriate means to achieve the end the proposition aspires to.

Now let's rebut their case. Their first argument was on this principle, and they had two things about decreasing the coercion of lobbying and this free-riding principle. So, first on lobbying. First of all, we would just like to point out that the way they promote democracy is to strip people of their right to freely associate. That seems a little bit contradictory. But on the point of lobbying, we have two responses. First, we think that their policy actually distorts the balance of power even further. The left has limited political capital, and by giving overwhelming voices to the employed through unionization, you strip the unemployed of their rights even further. And second, we think that often unions lobby for harmful and protectionist policies, things like anti-immigrant and minority legislation, that harm people even further. Now on this larger principle of free riding. So we have three responses here as well. First, they fail to give us any kind of special justification for why we need this policy, given the massive scale of coercion it entails. Second, it's entirely contingent on the idea that union membership actually benefits workers, and unions are a legitimate cause to contribute to. They have to win the practical to win the principle. But even if you don't buy any of this, they actually undermine their very principle of democracy because unions are fundamentally political actors. In order to achieve this principle of collective responsibility, you have to violate freedom of association, a baseline right for democracy. That's an overriding principle. Now let's talk about their practical argument about protecting workers' rights. Their mechanism for this is strengthening unions. We have four responses. First, unions are ill-suited to advocate for workers in an increasingly globalized economy where firm and nation-specific advocacy is just not adequate. But second, they're structurally unrepresentative because they trapped tenure over the democratic will of the people. Third, we actually make unions worse on their side of the house because they have built-in monopolies on membership, meaning that they have no incentive to approve to draw more members. But take them at their highest ground. Unions accomplish everything they set out to do. Those benefits come at a massive cost that's devastating both to the workers they're trying to protect and to the economy as a whole. We'll explain more on how this is true later, but the harms that accrue from the benefits they claim just dwarf any advantages on their side.

Now let's introduce the first substantive argument from side on position on how this policy constitutes an unjustifiable violation of our freedom to associate. Why do we care about freedom of association? We think that for democracies to be legitimate, people have to freely associate to self-determine, spread ideas, and build coalitions. They violate it in three ways. First, for freedom of association to be meaningful, it has to include your freedom not to associate with certain groups. Second, they're forcing people to contribute 2-5% of their income to these unions. But third, compelling union membership is essentially forcing people to associate with the political groups that they fund. The Labour Party in the United Kingdom, I'll take you in a moment, received 90% of its funding in 2016 from one union. Those groups are inextricably tied. Just as we would never force a Muslim farmer in India to join the BKS union, which is closely tied to the right-wing nationalist Hindu BJP party, we would not force someone to support abortion. That is just fundamentally abhorrent. Many workers feel unable to join a union out of fear that they will be discriminated against by their employers. How do you correct this coercion? Look, we acknowledge that this is a problem, but we think that on your side, coercion is actually much, much worse, because instead of societal suggestions, it's an explicit mandate that you join these unions. The coercion is just inevitably worse.

But now on to our second argument about extensive union membership creating economically devastating effects. Remember that this takes their entire practical case on its very highest ground. Unions achieve every single one of their goals. That creates three massive harms. The first one is decreasing labor mobility, and this affects the very stakeholders they think they're winning in today's debate. Unions are tied to one industry, one country, and often one employer, and lose size and influence if labor is too mobile. So they undermine it in three ways. One, they entrench dying industries. Consider unions' contribution to the chokehold that the dying U.S. coal industry has on regions of that country. Second, they make it really difficult to fire people. Teachers unions in the global south, for example, make it so that in places like Brazil, teachers can be fired, are essentially untouchable, and routinely don't show up to work. But finally, they create wage distortion. In the short term, they do increase wages in unionized industries, making them relatively more attractive than non-unionized industries. Even though those industries might be more productive and going towards them might be more sustainable for workers in the long term. What we do through all of these three things is we increase the risk for and consequences of industry-wide unemployment, meaning swaths of people lose their livelihoods, like they did in the English coal industry in the 1980s. Our second layer under this argument is increasing unemployment. What do unions do? They increase wages by threatening strikes and preventing new hires, and they decrease competition by monopolizing the provision of labor and making it hard to hire skilled unemployed workers over less skilled employed workers. This leads to things like in the United States, states with 20% higher union membership have had 16% higher unemployment over the last 30 years. Why is unemployment so much more relatively harmful than low wages? First, the unemployed are the poorest and most vulnerable in society. Second, they're much less likely to get retrained after they lose their job. But finally, there's immense societal stigma surrounding unemployment, meaning that in areas with high unemployment, there are immensely high rates of depression and alcoholism. That's why we are so in opposition to their policy. But our final layer under this argument is on how they decrease overall national productivity. Through a couple of mechanisms. First, they make it impossible for small businesses to enter industries and innovate. This is because labor costs become prohibitively expensive, and because you decrease competition, you decrease the incentive for entrenched industry giants to actually pursue innovation and productivity but beyond that they actually increase cyclical strikes on their side of the house consider the 2014 platinum mining
strike in South Africa that led to 2.25 billion dollars in lost revenue for the industry and a million dollars in lost wages for the industry and a billion dollars in lost wages for the

workers who participated. That's massively, massively destabilizing. On their side of the house, in the long term, we actually see increases in price because of decreased productivity and overly strong union advocacy. But furthermore, in the long term, because you decrease growth, you decrease wages for the very workers that they advocate for, the only group that they have any chance of winning on their side of the House. Because we believe in protecting everyone's democratic rights and economic well-being, we are so proud to oppose this motion. Thank you.

And now to continue the case for the first opposition, please welcome us. Thank you. Panel, democracy is dying at the hands of big business enforcing their will on crippled workers, with the powerless vote which is diluted through processes such as gerrymandering and voter suppression. This proposal was the only way to restore the vote these people were being stripped of. Any sort of dissenting opinion on this issue was unguided, uneducated, and unconstitutive of the very problems these workers faced. This opposition has to start engaging with the fact that these people were being locked out of democracy itself.

Two questions in rebuttal. First, on the feeble response that we got on our principle. Their attempt to push the very economists that represent... Their push was to say that the very economists that push for things like tax cuts that hurt those workers were the ones that they picked to represent these workers. Let that sink in, panel, because this side of the house was the very side that wanted the big businesses to represent those people. Pushed for legislation that actively harmed them. They wanted to hide behind the veneer about democratic rights. Say that this was a political organ and therefore in and of itself was democratic unrepresentative. What they missed under this point is the fact that they were currently being stripped of their democratic right and this was the only way to restore that. The only response of this whole issue was to say that this is in and of itself coercive because we're stripping the rights of workers to make their choice.

For example, a Muslim worker who joined a union was now being forced to support a Hindu charity. This cookie cutter argument did not stand in this debate, because what we stood behind was a democratised union that allowed the voices of people to be heard. We allowed a Muslim voting bloc in a union to elect things like Muslim representatives. That allowed for things like the Islamic Farmers Union in Gujarat to push for things like Ramadan leave. That was extremely important and something this opposition has to stand behind. But secondly, let's be very, very comparative. Under their side of the house, the people that they wanted to champion, the Muslim voter, aren't heard at all. That is something that this opposition has to live with. We do not have to prove any practical argumentation like this opposition want to seem to burden for us. We just have to show that the current system, whereby the voice of the most disenfranchised was more likely to be heard under our side of the house, so a cookie-cutter argument on the stripping of the rights of workers did not stand. Even if we say the right to affiliation was something that extended to workers, that only extended to the extent that you could express that right to affiliation, we think we did that when people were able to choose things like the union they were part of. This opposition needs to start engaging with that principle.

Let's look at practical effects. This is where the majority of the material was predicated and it was quite delusional. This opposition says that unions are awful for a couple of reasons. First, because they have things like tenure involved and you have corrupt figures at the top and that's really bad. This opposition needs to start engaging with the reality of unions we get. Because tenure only happens to the extent where workers are reluctant to join unions in the first place. When they have the ability to influence those unions directly, that is how you get through to things like corruption in tenure. The next push of this opposition was to say that globalisation is happening, and beyond saying the word globalisation, they didn't really give much analysis there. We tell you that the very things that labour unions deal with, things like the displacement of workers, and things like the emergence of new industries are dealt with by unions in a way that is humane and not just by looking at a spreadsheet like The Economist under the inside of the House. Because when labour unions are able to discuss things like contracts or slowing down particular dismissals of workers, that is something that is particularly good in dealing with globalisation. The next thing this opposition says is labour labour unions lead to bad mobility of the workforce. I'm going to address this more in my substantive, but we said that we didn't care about labour union mobility insofar as under their side of the house, the more worse workers were the ones that were suffocated and crippled under the boots of neoliberalism. The very shallow response to our material was to say that unemployed workers were the ones that were going to be stuffed over by this. The thing to know is that unions help these people the most. Because when they push for things like greater employment or a quota on the number of employees you have, or when they push for things like retraining, if you get let go from a job, you're able to find employment for. Or when they push for things like better wages, those are all things that help the most distant drive times. But in addition to that, let's just note under this point, this is all because we just did not want to engage in the huge benefits we got when hundreds of people assembled and fought for higher wages, fought for better conditions. Let's be very clear. If we can see all of their material, at best they've got a 0.2% increase in GDP growth rate. We're not going to trade that off at the expense of increases in wages and

standards for workers. Two points of substantive depth. Firstly, why compulsory union membership is a necessary organ for a healthy economy. The economy suffocates under the boots of the bourgeoisie as American men in suits desperately pursue already inflated profits. Unions remedy a sick economy in three ways. The first is that they prevent crises of unemployment. Two reasons under this. They slow otherwise rapid rates of dismissal that occur in the coal industry this opposition wants to talk about. Because unions have the ability, no thank you, to negotiate things like contracts that stagger and slow down lay-ups and that allows the government to negotiate things like contracts that stagger and slow down lay-ups. And that allows the government to impose things like policy that allows them to transition out of it. That was extremely important. The very economic material this opposition wanted to stand behind did not stand in the face of that. But secondly, they softened the harms of unemployment. Because they were able to invest in things like retraining or force companies to compensate their workers with high severance packages, for example. This allowed the effects of unemployment to be far less worse and you have things like greater spending under our side of that. The second thing it did is it reduced economic inequality. I'll take a POI if you guys have one. Sure. Would you force a German citizen to join the Christian Democratic Political Party if that Christian Democratic Political Party legislates an increase in say environmental protection? I mean, I guess you guys have to start engaging with our case, which is that we have multiple unions, we have democratisation, you can't run a cookie cutter stop and ask it every time. So this reduces economic inequality through things like minimum wages and protections. Huge inequality is awful under their side of the house when the elites hoard money. Three reasons why. First, because people need money to invest, to innovate, to send their children to school. Second, poverty in and of itself, or inequality, creates bad social problems like time, which in turn has economic harms like property damage. Third, it leads to decreased spending when the rich is to save their money rather than investing it. We thought the middle class working folks were the ones that led to things like cyclical rises in economic growth. But third, and this is responsive to their material, is unions were actually guardians of market competition because unions advocated against things like monopoly policy. They wanted to have more people that they can negotiate with and they had an incentive to do so in parliament. This point in and of itself is debate-winning, because it shows that the economy is far better, and importantly, it proves that their minute economic benefit, at best, is not worth the sacrifice of stripping the poorest of their wealth and their right to democratic representation.

Let's look, secondly, at unions and women and minorities. Note that this is comprehensively responsive to that peculiar POI we got before. Unions rectify the travesty that is the failure of other civic institutions in the vote to represent minority communities. Not a few things. Women in unions earn 14 cents more than women outside of unions. That is a huge, undeniable benefit we get. Let's just think about a world where all women are a part of that union. That is so good. And especially when you have things like collective bargaining, which gets rid of things like pay secrecy. That was particularly beneficial for the fight against the Pay Act. But unions have fought hard for minority communities. When an Islamic worker union is able to negotiate things like Ramadan leave in Gujarat, that is something that's really beneficial. And that's responsive to their material. Under our side of the house, we have huge voting blocks of those minorities that are able to push for more of those legislations. The panel recognises this opposition needs to start dealing with the reality that is a lack of democratic representation. It wasn't enough for them to say that the rich would have ten more dollars to Google Profit Books. And now to continue the case for the position, please welcome Aditya.

Three things in this speech. First, two strategic errors that come out of the proposition bench, then two questions about the principle and practical, and then our third argument. Three things in this speech. First, two strategic errors that come out of the proposition bench, then two questions about the principle and practical, and then our third argument.

First, on the two strategic errors, we think the first one is that Australia does not meet the exceedingly high burden that we told you about in Opposition 1. What was that? At the point where 93% of workers in the United States reject unions,

and we don't think this is idiosyncratic to the free market loving America, but 84% of workers worldwide reject unions, we think it is very important for a compelling account to come out of proposition why government and why structurally

unrepresented unions know what's best for workers who want what's best for themselves and what's best for their families in order to make that kind of choice. We think this is also inherently important because unions are political actors. They need to tell you why they want to buy this kind of freedom of choice. But we think the second strategic error that comes out of the proposition bench is at face they are fundamentally uncomparative. First, on the stands. Look, we're not heartless Tories. We're not advocating for big business taking over the world. What we tell you in opposition is we think workers should have protections. They say, well, independent commissions are controlled by big business taking over the world. What we tell you in opposition is we think workers should have protections. They say independent commissions are controlled by big business. We think that's factually false. Look to India where their 2002 National Labour Commission, for example, instituted not only worker protections but also capital restrictions so you saw the middle class rising. We think those are the sorts of labour commissions we would like to have. But second, Australia is fundamentally uncomparative when it comes to trade-offs. A policy like this advantages some over the others. We need to hear a compelling account in Government 3 of why these trade-offs are justified. Third, we think they are uncomparative on the sophistication of our case. It is not enough for Australia's two to come up here and say in response to three different mechanisms that take their best case scenario and say you still get economic devastation and just say in response to our practical arguments, we don't care about labour mobility. This is a fundamentally non-engagement on the Australian bench. We think they are losing

the practical debate here. Let's go on to the questions. First on the practical, we think Australia is behind the principle at the point where all three of their so-called principles are contingent on them proving practical benefits. But we think they're also behind on the practical at the point where they say they don't care about our own practical argumentation, and they literally spend less than a quarter of their case in Proposition 1 on practical arguments. Let's talk about the one stakeholder that Australia wanted to talk about. They tried to tell you that this was better for workers. We told you no for five different reasons. First, because unions are structurally unsuited to representing workers. We tell you that at the point where unions want workers to stay within the industries, they don't actually retrain the workers for better jobs than Australia somehow thinks they believe they get retraining. But second, unions are unrepresented. I will show this in our third argument, and I'll fly it when we get there, but essentially, because of the lack of accountability and the lack of representation, what you have is structurally unrepresented union leadership making political gains at the expense of the workers. Third, we think there is no actual incentive for unions to make better policy at the point where you have compulsory membership. They would like to tell you that unions are automatically competitive in their roles because people can just choose which unions they join. No, here's why we think that's false. Large unions dominate these kinds of industries. Moreover, we would tell you that in these given large industries, unions have every incentive to collude. So effectively what you have is you have one singular union monopolizing labor. At this point, we don't think that you give them any incentive to actually push for change. But fourth, our second argument takes this increase in wages, this increase in bargaining power that comes out of the first and the third argument as its foundation. And we show you why you create economic devastation for the workers, specifically by increasing sectoral unemployment. Then, the second thing we talk about on this practical benefit to small businesses. Here's what comes out in a second. They tell you that unions are guardians of market competition. They call this argument debate winning. Okay, let's take them at their best and say unions want to guard market competition. Unfortunately, the practical outcomes are that they don't. What do we tell you in opposition 1? We tell you that at the point where unions raise costs for small businesses and increase the threat of litigation, small businesses are shut out of the market and you only entrench large businesses. Why is this so important? Because the lack of competition that they themselves want decreases jobs, decreases wages, increases prices, and moreover we say it magnifies the risk of sexual unemployment at the point where dining industries can't even vitalize under their side of the house. We also tell you about the unemployed. We tell you why it increases harms for the most vulnerable. Why do you need to care about this? Why is this the most strategically important part of our case? We would say at the point where Australia, if the question of practical is even ambiguous, Australia cannot win because their principles are entirely contingent on the practical.

Let's talk about the principles. They have three so-called principles. First is this idea of equitable democratic representation. It is contingent on them proving first an increase in political representation, and second an increase in political capital. That's what they tell you in Prop 1. Second, they have an inability to consent. We think this is again contingent on proving that there are practical harms and third, we have a free-riding principle. Look, this is literally contingent on them proving that unions are actually beneficial for the economy at the point where they have no practical stains in this debate. We don't think free-riding actually matters. But don't let them use scare tactics to tell you that free-riding is bad. No, no, no. Free. Free writing is freedom of choice. We think it's fundamentally undemocratic when you have medical freedoms that are violated because you're forced to be associating with someone else. Yes? How is giving people a say... How is giving a say to workers in politics, regardless of the implications of that, contingent on any outcome? Okay, so here's one you don't actually... It's contingent on you proving that workers get a larger say in politics. Here's why you don't do that. Three reasons. First, we tell you the political capital is limited on the left, so what you do is you distort power between the unemployed and the employed. At that point, their one-person, one-vote principle doesn't stand out because they're not even upholding it for the most vulnerable in society. But second, we would say, because this increase in bargaining power doesn't actually functionally materialize, we tell you that unions no longer have any incentive to actually represent the workers that they think they want to, because union membership is now compulsory. None of their principles stand in this realm.

Let's talk about a third argument, about harmful political consequences. First, we think unions are structurally unrepresentative. Why? First, because in highly unionized firms that are less competitive, and this is what you see in highly unionized firms, not just firms that elect one or two unions, the minority force bonds with tenure. So what you see in UK teachers' unions is that the old establishment leads, with no incentive to let in minorities, who are often new, young entries into the field, into leadership. But second, even apathetic members forced to be there don't actually devote time to elections, so there's no surge in representation under Proposition's model. But third, we tell you that leaders are coercive and use fear to stay in power. In Britain, their largest union united literally blacklisted workers for speaking out against leadership. So let's say that workers start voting in union elections. It doesn't matter because union leadership coerces them to vote however leadership wants. There is no surge in representation under their model. Second, you could say that unions are unaccountable and as such we can bother sway. First, this happens because there's no member check because it's undemocratic. Second, there's no market check. We tell you that unions collude. And third, there's no institutional check because unions are responsible to anyone else. Given this lack of accountability, there's no institutional check, because unions are responsible to anyone else. Given this lack of accountability, given this lack of representation, why does this create harms, especially in a world where they themselves tell you about increased power? First, because it creates discrimination. We see that unions actively shut out minorities to protect the larger part of their base. Like in the United States, where unions stood against the civil rights, we think incidentally this clashes with the 40 seconds worth of material that they brought you in Proposition 2. Second, we think this creates tacit discrimination at the point where unions still distort policy in favour of the employed over the unemployed. We saw unions in Germany standing against things like rail-car protections, standing against things like inimmigrant emiss laws.

But third, we think we create political corruption. This is often tacit At the point where leaders pursue Southgate against the interests of their workers, we think this is what happened in South Africa, for example, where union leaders who wanted political gain told the police to fire upon their own striking mine workers. At the end
of the day, if side, all side government can show us that they might tangentially help some workers, we tell you what I force for them and for everyone else in the economy. That's why they lose.

And now to continue the case for the proposition, please welcome Jack. Yeah. Second off is totally right. The burden these guys set for us was exceedingly high. We did not have to prove that all unionised workers and the economy as a whole were 100% going to benefit from this policy. We have to show you that overwhelmingly, when wages went up by 7% in unionised industries, that helped the vast majority of workers. We have to show you that when workers had legal protection from being unfairly dismissed, that did not exist for non-unionised workers on their side, that helped almost all, if not all, workers. So it's not true that we have to prove 100% of cases we are the best possible side. We just are saying on our side, firstly, that we help the vast majority of workers, but secondly, that we give them a voice in unions and we give them a voice in the workplace that they otherwise would not have had, and that in and of itself is a good that we should value. I'm going

to do two things in this bit. First, I'm going to prove that our policy is crucial to democratic representation, and second, I'm going to explain why this is best for workers on a practical level. On the first, the principle. First thing I'm going to do here is explain to you again our principle, the same as this team, because it's not contingent. There are two parts to it. First, we told you that democratic representation was foundational to workers' rights and just as your right to vote was absolute regardless of how people voted or the practical impacts of having a democracy and having people vote, we said union membership and your ability to advocate for your own views and represent yourself within the workplace were absolute regardless of practical outcomes. It was not a contingent principle. Secondly, we told you that it amounted to theft when 89% of US workers were able to claim the benefits of the end without paying union dues. They tell us that free ride is a contingent on practical outcomes. No analysis as to why, and it's pretty clear on our side that it is unjust. That's why on those two levels alone, the fact that people need democratic representation because workers' union matter, because workplaces play such a crucial political role in people's lives, in and of itself, wins us the debate. But let's look at their principles. They tell us one thing, which is that people deserve freedom of association and we should protect that above all else. They give you two reasons as to why. First, they tell you that joining a union should itself be a free choice. Two responses to that. Firstly, it is an unfortunate reality for this opposition team and for most workers around the world, because there are so many reasons why the choice not to join a union on their side is not a free one either. We gave you five independent reasons as to why you could not really decide to join a union. That was firstly, you had a lack of information. Secondly, you tended to optimism. Ten years out, you did not predict the fact that you would be laid off. Thirdly, there was social stigmatisation when only very few workers were parts of unions. Fourth, the fact that unions were way more expensive on their side to join because so few people were in them. And fifth, and most importantly, that employers were likely to discriminate against people when not everyone was unionised. Because firstly, they could just not hire unionised workers and cover that up. But secondly, even if they couldn't do that, they would favour groups of workers, like part-time workers, who on their side were disproportionately not unionised. That means on their side too, it is not a free choice not to associate with unions. But the reason why, and this is important, the coercion that is more on our side than on their side too, it is my free choice not to associate with unions. But the reason why, and this is important, the coercion that is more on our side than on their side, is because on our side you have a voice. You can vote within unions, you can represent yourself. So even if, at their best case scenario, as they said, on both sides coercion exists, on our side, when you're coerced into a union, you still have representation, you still can express yourself democratically, something that does not happen when you're just locked out in the first place. The second reason they give you why freedom of political association matters is because freedom of political association matters. Notice that's an argument for our side, and I'm going to use their example here to demonstrate that. They tell us that when an Indian Muslim joins a Hindu union, that is not what that Indian Muslim would want. True responses, and this is crucial because it undermines all of their analysis on freedom of association. Firstly, note that on our side, when there are more Indian Muslims in unions, they have a say and they can shape policies in their favour. That's material we gave you at second. The reason that doesn't happen on their side is because of a collective action problem, whereby any single Muslim person won't join because they themselves can't effect enough change. But secondly, and this is so crucial, notice the dire implication of their position on Indian Muslims and Hindu unions on their side. On their side, Indian Muslims just do not get represented in unions at all. They get paid significantly lower wages, they are more likely to be fired because they don't have legal protection. And for a side who wanted to champion these minority groups, they literally screwed them over at the point at which they never got union representation in the first place, and were never able to derive those benefits. At the end of this principle, two things should be clear. First, our principle is not contingent. Your right to have a say in your workplace and to match that say to your employer is fundamental. But secondly, all of their principal material, A, does not stand up, but second, it's terrible for the groups that they want to support.

So, let's look, secondly, at what is best for your workers pragmatically. This is where USA catches most of their bets in this debate. I'm going to deal with five points under this. First thing they tell you is that strikes are destabilising to the economy and bad for producers. Firstly, that's true, that's how you affect change. When you have a bargaining chip such as the fact that you can reduce the amount of money a company can make, you're able to have a say. And it was a fatal strategic error for this company to put so much time into that, only to tell you that it was a waste of political capital for people to expend energy on unions. Because the important point here was that being part of a union created political capital that would to expend energy on unions. Because the important point here was that being part of a union created political capital that would not otherwise exist. You do not have bargaining power over your employer on their side. When you have a union, you do. This does not heat into any other form of bargaining power. Second point they're telling you, it's harder to fire people. Like, absolutely, it is harder to fire people. That's like a really good thing. And all we're saying is that unfairly firing people should be illegal. Obviously, if Brazilian teachers don't show up to work, there is just cause to fire them. Unions won't stop you doing that. But in the vast majority of cases, when people are taken in a moment, are fired unfairly, we think they absolutely should have a right to legal counsel, but they do not have it when they're not part of unions. Go. Let's talk about free writing. If the Democrats in the US legislate environmental protections a non-excludable good, why should any random citizen not be forced to join that party? No, no, like, people pay tax. They absolutely do participate in environmental causes. Like, free-riding is literally the best analogy to tax, right? I might not believe 100% of the Democrats' policies or the Republicans' policies, but I get some benefit and have to pay tax so that I only chop the benefits that's a mistake for our nation. That is absolutely the right comparison to make. Third point I tell you, unpractical. Small businesses will shut down because they're scared of litigation. Firstly, know that that awkward part of the topic that says large industries now actually becomes so meaningful here, because we are only talking about large industries. But secondly, know that beyond some analysis, presumably the way in which businesses will respond to our policy is not to just shut down and capitulate. They're probably more likely to just stop laying off workers unjustly and stop exploiting those labourers. That means you don't get small businesses shutting down, you just get better treatment of workers. Next thing they tell you is that unions are a monopoly and they won't be democratic on our side, they won't reform. First, there are internal accountability mechanisms that work for the most part under the status quo and will continue to work on our side. When the head of a union does not want to be voted out of that position by not representing their members, they will listen to what those union members have to say. Secondly, as we told you down the bench, in most industries there were multiple unions creating the competition. But thirdly, know how unions behave when they aren't guaranteed workers, and this is a point for our side. They're likely to engage in things like unnecessary strides in order to get attention and claim workers. That goes away on our side. A couple of final points on the economy as a whole that they bring you. First, they tell you you get increased unemployment. First, I'm just going to reject that you get less employment. Unions put up barriers to replacing labour with capital. That's the first response. Less automation, more negotiating power means workers are less likely to be fired, there'll be more employment. But secondly, when 100% of workers are unionised, it's unattractive to fire them and you're more likely to just reduce the pay salaries of people at the top of corporations. Finally, on the point about economic growth, it was very nebulous, but I'm going to point out here, as we told you down the bench, that we would rather value basic work protections that matter so much more, like getting higher pay, like getting guaranteed health insurance over a small increase to GDP. At the end of this debate, know that people absolutely deserve representation, and more importantly than
that, if this is what they want this debate to be about this is way better for workers overall that's why we propose.

This side proposition makes some wholly unoriginal American jokes and some scare tactics about corporations, but unfortunately that does not amount to engagement with our arguments. There's a lot going on in
this round, and I'll walk you through why side opposition is one. So, what does side

opposition have to do? They have to show why every worker must be forced to join a union in order to gain benefits for workers and wider societies. Why is this reasonable? Because if you're hurting millions or literally billions of people with your policy, it's probably not justifiable. We think when you're affecting the entire globe, it's fair to have a pretty high burden. But second, they have to justify why it's okay to make a massive rights violation in order to do so, especially since we tell you we can still support standards done by independent commissions like you see in India. We just believe in achieving these through cooperation and not coercion. At the end of the day, this is a debate about trade-offs in compulsory union membership, not whether they think we ban unions or why it's a good idea to join them. So, first toy area of clash in today's round is that of the wider economy, which they generously get to in Prof 3 at 7 minutes and 45 seconds. This is important, because even if you grant them literally all of their case about workers, this is why we still win the round because there are billions of people they're ignoring who aren't employed in these sectors. That is the wider economy. How do they do this? First of all, productivity. This happens in two ways. The first is small businesses. Not to shock you, but small businesses can be part of large industries. So why do they shut down? Not only is there fear of retaliation, like the side competition responds to, but they literally cannot afford the higher cost that unions implement. That's not something they engage with. So, the second way you hurt productivity is because when you increase cost of products, people can no longer afford to buy them. That's what decreases economic growth. So, why is productivity important? First of all, it's what creates the tax revenue to provide social services. Second, in the long run, that decreases wages. That's really important because when businesses are making less money and the economy is weaker, people cannot be paid as much. But third, because growth concretely reduces poverty, that's why we've seen global poverty go from 35% in 1990 to only 10% in 2013. Second way is unemployment. We would tell you that, first of all, people are literally fired off to their side of the house. That's like a statistical fact. In places where unionization is 20% higher, employment is 60% lower, they cannot sue their way out of businesses having to fire people because they cannot afford to keep them. But why is that worse than what they say? We tell you that the unemployed are the most vulnerable in this society. They're the most poor, and they're the least likely to be retrained. The longer they're out of employment, the more their skills decay, and the less the economy gets those valuable skills. But finally, because in the long run, social services for these people decrease, and the more the government has to spend on social services for the unemployed, the more they have to cut in other areas, which is crucial because that cuts into funds for retraining as well. But the third way they hurt more people, we tell you, is because unions structurally hurt the vulnerable. Why? Because they want to protect their own and protect wages. They see people like immigrants as a threat to that. That's why unions across the world oppose immigration. They structurally don't represent women either. Even though women are in over half of unions, they're barely 10% of union leaders. But we thank side proposition for trying to explain misogyny to me. But then, what is the next thing they bring to you? They bring to you the idea that overall, they create an aggregate growth. I can tell you that's not true because first of all, all of these harms still apply. Second, because you have more consumption in the economy when there are more people with jobs. But finally, because the contracts they talk about cannot prevent people from firing workers or replacing them when they cannot afford them. There is no way for retraining for contracts to solve that problem. At that level, they hurt way more people when they help. That's why they do this argument. Second key area of clash

in today's round, which side is best for workers? We tell you, this is really important because this is the demographic they spend almost all of their pace on. So if we win this argument, we win the round. First question under here, does union power actually increase? We give you a couple of reasons we think this isn't true. First, unions lose an incentive to perform when people are forced to join them. We think, rather, they collude with each other to take away the choice that the proposition creates an illusion of. But second, we tell you unions have huge structural problems that prevent them from being effective. That is, they don't cooperate with labor mobility, they don't understand like the global movement of labor, and they don't understand the fact that most labor is part-time but unions negotiate for full-time workers. But third, we tell you unions are structurally unrepresentative at the level where turnout in union elections is under 20% as is. We don't think it's really realistic that it's going to change under their side of the house. But take them at their highest ground and say, yes, unions are effective. Why is that? First of all, we tell you they destroy labor mobility. That is crucial because what unions want to do is keep the stranglehold they have on dying industries in order to hold their power. Like they did with coal in the United States and the United Kingdom. So what does that do? That creates unemployment across entire sectors. But it also means people cannot be effectively retrained because unions structurally oppose people being retrained and leaving their industry. But second, because unions fight for the privilege. That goes back to the part-time example where they only fight for full-time workers because that's who votes in their union election, so these minimum hours contracts mean people cannot get part-time jobs. But third, because these past economic harms I just mentioned affect union workers, which means when you see rising costs to the global economy, that hurts workers too, meaning their real wages are lower even if they're getting paid more. That's true across the world. But fourth, because they increase these costs, often businesses are afraid to hire people and afraid to fire them. That is why you speed the pace of automation, essentially putting more people out of work, which again, is legal. We help their demographic. If this is at all ambiguous, they lose the round, given that their principal argument is contingent on the practical, which I'll get to in a bit.

Now, let's talk about the principal. Why is this important? Because states shouldn't abuse the vast force of powers. So, freedom of association is what we bring to you. They give you a few reasons they think it's structurally acceptable to violate that. The first is political representation. We tell you, that is contingent on the idea that they actually improve political representation. Do put the right to it now. But we also tell you, at the level where unions are very unrepresentative and often just lead based on tenure and don't do what workers want, they undermine this. But second, they tell you people can't consent because they don't have enough information. Yes? Do you think more pensions, more health insurance, higher wages, and guaranteed legal protection or a bit of GDP growth, benefits workers more? We would tell you that when you hurt the global economy and you increase layoffs by up to 60%, you definitely hurt more people than you help. I already said that, I'm not sure why it's so unclear. But here's why workers can consent. First of all, we tell you, yeah, workers probably do know their sectors, pretty well understand the consequences, but second, we don't think that government plutocrats are necessarily in a better place to make decisions for those workers and force them to join unions. But the third thing they bring to you is free riding. We don't think paying taxes is the same thing as forcing someone to join a political party. But furthermore, we tell you again, this does not obligate people to join a union. It's contingent on the benefits that they prove. Choice at the end trumps this. The last thing they bring to you to respond to a principle is the idea of coercion. We say, first of all, we think it's unrealistic that 85% of workers are all joining, not joining because they're afraid of coercion. But second, unions coerce people more when they put people on scab lists and threaten them in their homes for daring to defy the union. But third, at the level where the state is telling you, you literally cannot get a job, you cannot put food on the table, unless you join a political organization. And then, these unions take your hard earned pay, that we find much more coercive. Why is that important? Because when people do not have freedom of association, they lose their right to fully participate in a democratic structure. Right now, we give you choice, they give you reasons, it might be a good idea to join the union, but that's not the debate. We ask them to engage with that and that is why we are proud to oppose. We will now start Opposition Speaker for their speech.

Australia's job in this debate was not to prove that this House should not ban unions. It was to prove that mandating union membership, forcing people to join these unions, creates overwhelming economic benefits both for workers and for society as a whole, but also that those benefits are so overwhelming that it justifies violating fundamental democratic liberties. They failed on both counts, and at the very best,

their case is a laundry list of reasons why it might be a good idea to join a union. Two questions in this debate, first on principle and second on practical. Let's start on the principle, because they are massively behind on this account. Their entire principled case is reliant on the assumption that unions are the only way to increase democratic representation, that forcing someone to politically associate with a certain group is the best way to increase their democratic rights, and that these unions actually increase representation for disadvantaged groups when they skew representation for the most advantaged of those disadvantaged groups, and actually force people who don't want to engage in unions into these groups. It's just fundamentally flawed. But what do we hear on our principle of freedom of association? They told you, well, because you can choose which union you're forced to join, that means that you're democratically represented. We would say that these unions are always politically charged, and overwhelmingly collude with one another, and are dominated by individual actors, which means that this is fundamentally not true. What does this mean? It means that an Indian farmer who is Muslim is forced to join a union network that advocates for nationalist Hindu policies. We reject this. It means that immigrants in Europe are forced to endorse anti-immigrant policies. It means that African Americans in the United States are forced to endorse anti-minority policies advocated for by polluting networks of unions. We win this debate outright because of this principle.
Because we believe you should not violate fundamental democratic liberties in the name of preserving democracy.
That's their case.
But now let's talk about the practical question, even though we clearly already won the principle in this round. What is Australia's story here?

They say you increase the power of workers, which increases their ability to advocate for themselves and achieve benefits. At its best, we took their best case scenario as the basis of our entire second argument. Unions do everything that they set out to do. Let's talk about three demographics. First, the workers that are the only demographic they have a chance of winning in today's debate. What did we tell you? We tell you, unambiguously, unions lead to more unemployment. Unions actually decrease in quality on their side of the house because they don't have to compete. Labour mobility decreases, something they apparently don't care about, leading to massive sectoral unemployment that robs millions of people of their livelihoods. Why does that benefit the workers they champion? But now let's talk about two groups that they really didn't touch at all in this debate. The first one is unemployed workers. We tell you that unions structurally advocate for the employed overwhelmingly more than the unemployed, distorting policy in their favor at the expense of the most vulnerable populations that we should care about in this world. They are the poorest. They are much less likely to get retrained. There is immense societal stigma against them. We think it's demoralizing to constantly be told that you don't contribute and that you're not a valuable member of society. And these groups are often the worst victims of the negative political consequences that unions advocate for, things like anti-immigrant and minority policies. This is the most important demographic in this round. It is the most vulnerable, and we have the largest obligation to protect them.

Now let's talk about the idea of economic growth, which they dismiss as a couple of upticks in percentage of GDP. They misunderstand the importance of economic growth. It's not just numbers. When the economy grows, that benefits everybody. It means more jobs, higher wages, benefiting everybody that they advocate for, and the swaths of people that they completely forget about in today's debate. We believe in protecting the fundamental rights of everyone in society. We believe in protecting people's economic rights, and we don't think that violating our democratic rights is the way to preserve democracy. That's why we're so proud to oppose.

Now to conclude the case for the proposition and to do it as a whole, please welcome Matt. Thank you. Panel, do not let this opposition deceive you. Because they talked a lot about increases in GDP. They talked a lot about somehow keeping more jobs. But the actual links between the existence of unions and the actual links between their model and those outcomes were completely asserted and under-explained. This opposition talked a lot about unions and corruption and collusion, yet ignored the specifics of our model, which focused on things like democracy, anti-corruption policy, and multiple unions being effective.

And no, the extension of their argumentation about democracy was to say that democracy as a whole was corrupt. If it was true that you could not consent to choosing a union, if it was true that you could not consent to vote, then this opposition stood against democracy. That's why we go on this debate.

Two further reasons. Firstly, because we gave the workers a voice, and secondly, because we helped the workers achieve the outcomes we cared about. On the first, we gave the workers the voice. Opposition never really gave a substantiated response to our principle about representation and the equalising force between fat cats and the worker until second opposition when they tell you that well that's completely contingent on representation. But that's when our model as opposed to the generalised conception of unions they had was so crucial because democracy, multiple unions and anti-corruption law didn't just apply to the Indian Hindus but everyone else. That was a benefit only our side claimed. But let's be comparative on the idea of representation because even if they could show that, well, in their base case scenario, 49% of the people that weren't in the majority weren't represented. Their side didn't give them a voice at all. They stood by appointing boards with no accountability. They stood by using the same government mechanisms that had locked out the worker for so long, we were unhappy to let those workers go on silence. Secondly, they never responded to all our material about consent.

We told you we did not have information. There was optimism bias, there was social stigmatisation, there were high costs when membership was low, and there was the massive coercive force of the fear your employer would discriminate against you because you were part of a union. And no, this was incredibly important material, because it undermines all of their material about freedom of association. Because you did not have that freedom when you were being coerced, you did not have that freedom when you could not consent. Unions were a far more clear way to representation.

And the final thing on the principle is they insufficiently responded to our principle about free writing. In a POI we made it very clear that tax was a perfect example of contributing to something even if you don't believe in 100% of its policies, after which they dropped that line. We won this debate on the principle like we told you from first week out.
This is about giving a voice to the workers who have been silenced for too long. That was what this opposition ignored, that was why we won this debate.

Secondly, on why we helped workers. This issue was marginal. The opposition makes two big claims. Firstly, they tell you that people will lose their jobs. But this is where their assertions were really their undoing. Because they never made the connection between not having unions and having more jobs. We told you in second speaker substantive that the comparative was not more people working, it was things like automation, it was things like offshoring. They never responded to that substantive. That means, at the end of this debate, we stood by slowing down the flow of people being replaced, we stood by reskilling the workers as they slowly got laid off, and protecting industries that weren't suffering from that. And this side, while claiming to be in favour of the worker, allowed unfettered automation and unfettered offshore.

And note, all their hums about putting food on the table and all their flowery rhetoric about the least vulnerable large, things like the rich person's glut, things like redistributing wealth so it can be spent more efficiently which mitigated their GDP arguments to some extent. Panel, rhetoric and assertions were not enough to get this opposition side across the line. They never dealt with the complexity of our principles, they never engaged the principle of representation and the specifics of our model and the democracy it stood behind. That's why we won this debate.

title: Online WSDC - PDOs - Ireland vs UAE
description: THBT large international institutions (e.g. UN and World Bank) should only accept female country delegates.
motion: THBT large international institutions (e.g. UN & World Bank) should only accept female country delegates.

argument_units.text: Panel, 25 years ago in the UN Summit for Women in Beijing, the world thought that change was being made. And yet 20 years on, progress is still hard to chart. Abortion rights are still patchy, violence against women, including rape as a weapon of war, is prevalent. Women in Honduras still suffer femicide, a death for simply being a woman, and seemingly first world countries, proper economic equality is still a distant dream in these. We recognise that the reason for this stagnancy is because women have never been given a fair chance to change their circumstances within global

organisations and we on Team Proposition pledge to change this and we recognise that to revert the systemic bias in the past, women need to lead the change and for this reason large international institutions should only accept female country delegates.

And today we as Team Proposition will be proving this to you through three main strands of argument. First, on principle and about how the nature of meritocracy under the status quo is simply fallacious and non-existent in regards to women and why this is therefore justified in order to ensure reparative justice. Second, why we get federal policy on our side of the house. And third, my second speaker will be discussing about how we get a perception of women on our side.

But first, what do we mean when we propose this motion? Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to depict the world under the status quo. We recognize, I'll take you in a second, that structures such as the UN have historically been unanimously dominated by men. When the UN first came into conception, out of about 800 representatives and officials, only four were women. And structurally, the foundations upon these international institutions have been made both by and for men. We now see the UN trying to combat this, trying to counteract this, and yet still today, only about 30% of delegates in the UN are women, and these women are still not in high-ranking positions, overwhelmingly. The UN is literally meant to be this sort of representation of equality, and one of the best international institutions in regards of gender equality, and at the point in which these biases still exist, we believe that it is justified to have this motion in place, but I'll take it now. Would you do this for national and local elections? And if not, why not? No, we would not do this for national and local elections. Well, we believe that large international institutions should only accept female country delegates. And if you don't send a female delegate, basically, you won't be represented. And then every other person underneath these representatives should also be women but first why just international why um just why not just some international institutions right we believe that women's rights are a global issue which has always been prevalent and the reason that we wouldn't have things such as quotas is because there are unique harms with these issues such as issues of tokenism where women are simply seen as sort of this tokenistic representation of quality and are often pushed around and brushed aside by men. But ladies and gentlemen, why in

principle do we owe this in women in order to combat historical injustices? We recognize that this idea of meritocracy ultimately does not uphold in the status quo due to two main reasons. First of all, structural historical inequalities against women, right? Educational access has been historically unjust in respect to women. For example, if you look at places like the UK, right, you literally see these high-ranking private schools such as Eton, Westminster, which is all male up till sixth form, in regards to men. And that's why, because of this increased access to education that men have had at the expense of women, you see things such as Cambridge University having all-female colleges in order to actually combat this and have an all-female cohort. Laws which discriminate women as well are extremely prevalent and therefore we believe that we must counteract this through a motion which unanimously declares that women uphold these positions. But second of all, ladies and gentlemen, perceptions of women which result in biases when it comes to hiring women in these jobs. Women are often perceived as being emotional sensitive and that's why if we look at women in power right if you look at someone like theresa may even though anyone in her position would realistically have struggled with the brexit scenario which she inherited she was perceived as this sort of weak fragile woman who was simply incompetent to do her job because of her states as a woman or if you even look at women who are respected right such as margaret thatcher and her this idea of her being an iron lady the reason that she is upheld at this high position is due
to the fact that she had stereotypically anti-female traits such as being harsh such as being uncompromising etc these are inherently sexist and therefore it's for these reasons

that women were not hired for such positions in the first place places such as the UN right have been unanimously male dominated and are still known as the sort of private gentleman's club. Statistically, due to implicit biases with women and gender roles, as well as in some cases explicit biases due to misogynistic rhetoric, men are far more likely to hire other men as opposed to women than women are. And that's why we see this sort of male hegemony and this decline and this masculine sense propagated even under the status quo and this means that this culture is extremely hard to break and even when women do get positions of power there are significant complaints of sexual harassment and general mistreatment due to their positions as women right in a world in which even the indian chief economist of the world bank reported sexual harassment we see that the only way to combat this issue is unanimously making these organizations women-dominated. Because as a principle, right, first of all, we owe this to women, because in order to actually have reparative justice, we need to put those who have been wronged in the past in the same position as past circumstances. Therefore, since these were unanimously male-dominated, we need to see a shift. shift and second of all having 50% women or having simple equity doesn't solve the issue of women being pushed around and it doesn't solve the issue of pervasive work culture which still

exists under the status quo but second why do we get better policy ladies and gents? We see that other non-gender related issues right can be just as well dealt with with women as men they aren't exclusive to men however even these so-called non-gender related issues are largely intersectional women are far more affected by poverty than men women are far more women in post-colonial societies suffer to a far greater extent than men and therefore women experience greater detriments firsthand even in regards to policies that appear to not be physically related to women under the status quo but second of all and most importantly female issues can exclusively be understood by women and we see two reasons for this right first women actually experience these issues and second of all that women are far more likely to focus on these issues right in a lot of third world countries, for example, in particular, men are often unlikely to even concede that these issues are prevalent under the status quo today. For example, in a lot of third world countries, they won't view the notion that women are seen as housewives or they're meant to be child bearers as necessarily detrimental, because they use rhetoric such as women are still equal, however, they're just different.
