title: Online WSDC - PDOs - Romania vs New Zealand
description:
First of the eliminatory rounds at the Online World Schools Debating Championship.

Motion: THBT large international institutions (e.g. UN & World Bank) should only accept female country delegates.
motion: THBT large international institutions (e.g. UN & World Bank) should only accept female country delegates.

argument_units.text: In a world where women are suffering from severe underrepresentation at all levels of political decision-making, at the level of heads of government, at the level of national legislatures. We think that the least we can do in this ever more globalized world is to offer them a real stake in political decision-making inside of international institutions. I'm so proud to propose. Two parts in my speech. One, I'll be setting up today's debate by providing a couple of clarifications. Secondly, I'll be going into my team's first two substantives. One, about how international institutions have an obligation to offer women an active stake in the decision-making process. Two, about how our measure will lead to a massive shift in perceptions. My second speaker will talk to you about how our policy represents a launching pad for national political careers for women.

First of all, a couple of clarifications. First, what sort of international institutions are we talking about? We're talking about institutions that are generally global in their scope, i.e. in the countries that are represented within them and in the scope of their decisions. Institutions like the United Nations, like the World Trade Organizations, like the World Health Organization, World Bank, IMF, and so on and so forth. Two, what does it mean for you to be a country delegate? We have to understand, first thing first, that a country delegate is oftentimes just one individual. In most international institutions, there is one individual that plays this role of representation. Two, they are generally appointed by governments at the discretion of those governments, meaning that they can choose generally whomever they want and whomever they think aligns with their own political position the best. Three, generally, they follow a mandate from the government. They generally have to follow some guidelines that are provided by political leaders. Fourthly, they do have negotiating power. This looks like country delegates within the United Nations negotiating on the specific wording of different resolutions in order to establish a formula that best fits their country's interests. So they are indeed bound to follow some guidelines from national governments,

but they also do have some real decision-making power. What does our policy do? We would think that the executive leadership of many of these organizations would impose that they would only receive female country delegates. This looks like the United Nations Secretariat telling countries that they will have to only bring female country delegates. We think that this is likely to be accepted by all nations in the world since they care more about being represented in one of the most important fora of international debate, international decision making, one second, rather than just giving up on a man that they wanted to put in that position. Before I go into my first substantive, if there are any POIs. When nations care deeply about their sovereignty and the ability to have individual choice, do you really think they're going to buy into you forcing them to make a particular decision? Yeah, ma'am, sure. Some of them might not be super happy at first about it, but even countries like Saudi Arabia currently have female diplomats within their ranks. We think that it's not as big of a change for them to give in to this sort of decision

just because they badly want that representation to happen first argument international institutions have an obligation to offer women an active stake in the decision-making process look the international bodies that we have in today's world are the ones who are supposed to be making decisions on the behalf of the entirety of humanity and affecting the entirety of humanity, and affecting the entirety of humanity. The legitimacy of decisions coming from these bodies at a global level rests on procedural ground, meaning that no... Thank you. Because of all religions, of all ethnicities have a say, that means that they are all bound by the decisions that these international institutions make, at least at the principal level. However, there is one glaring exception in today's world, and that is women. At all levels of political decision-making, women are being crowded out. In parliaments, at the level of who is an MP, in most countries, vastly dominated by men. At the level of heads of state, most of them in the world are men. So there is a systematic under-representation of women within most countries. Therefore, we think that in this current setup of these international institutions, no thank you, the decisions of these institutions are not international in scope. They're not global in scope because they leave out half of the world's population. In order for these decisions to be truly global and to hold legitimacy in front of all the people in this world, we have to fix the issue of representation.

Okay, why do international bodies have to impose this? Because realistically speaking, they're the only ones that can really do it. They're the only ones that have enough power and international clout and prestige to induce this form of representation. In the case of individual countries that may have sexist national governments, it is unlikely that they will take that position themselves and to appoint, for example, a female head of state. So we think that the only way to induce some form of representation is to force this thing at the level of national country delegates. We think that since countries desperately want a seat at the table in the most important fora, they're just going to accept it. Why national delegates though? Because they're the only real stakeholders in the decision-making process at level of most international institutions. If we talk, for example, about the staff of the United Nations Secretariat, although they do support the works of the United Nations, they're not the ones actively taking the political decisions. If we really want women to have, no thank you, active political decision-making power, they have to be part of the political decision-making process. That means to be a delegate who's the one voting on resolutions, voting on decisions of various fora. Why all countries? Because we think that these international institutions have equal obligations towards all of their member states. We acknowledge that there are many power disparities within these institutions, but we think that we should always err on the side of treating all states as equally as possibly, as equitably as possible. This is why on our side of the house, we think that this is an obligation that should be imposed on every single state, not on half of them, not on a couple of them. No, thank you. That's not enough. Note at the end of the house, we think that this is an obligation that should be imposed on every single state, not on half of them, not on a couple of them.
No, thank you. That's not enough. Note at the end of this argument, this is not contingent on pragmatics.

You do not have to have, even if there would exist some backlash, as team opposition might want to prove to you, we think that it doesn't matter. Because the only just decision to make is to have this representation happen in the first place. We never asked ourselves whether giving women suffrage would cause backlash or not because we didn't think that it was, no thank you, an important calculation to take into this process. This is our principle.

Two, this leads to a massive shift in perception, second argument. We think that although many of these institutions may not have effective decision-making power, they have a lot of symbolic clout. When the United Nations General Assembly convenes, all eyes in the international media are on them. Speeches inside of that forum are broadcasted around the world. In times of an international pandemic, the World Health Organization is no thank you looked at as being authoritative, as being a trendsetter. They're at the top of the global decision-making hierarchy, even if just at an image level. We think that this offers them enormous symbolic power. So we think that there would be an enormous impact if all of these national delegates would be women. Just imagine how Jacinda Ardern coming into the United Nations General Assembly with her baby made so many headlines around the world. Our policy would make even more. This would be the top of the town. What are the concrete impacts? First, at a broader level, we think that this is sending a signal that women are indeed competent and that they ought to take an active role in the decision making process. We think that this leads to more role models for young girls, more empowerment. But secondly, at a national level, we think that in the cases of systematically sexist countries, one powerful role model is enough to deeply shape perceptions. Benazir Bhutto, becoming the prime minister of Pakistan, made huge progress for the perception of women inside of Pakistan because it showed a powerful woman that was able to take decisions on her own. Even in the case of less sexist countries, we think that representatives like Nikki Haley, that ended up becoming the darling of the Republican Party, can still make huge progress for women's representation. So because we want to have women have at least one seat at the table, please vote proposition. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you.

So I guess we'll start. up. Forcing nations to send only female delegates to international institutions results in a complete collapse of these institutions and any legitimacy of their decisions. They are not only perceived as less legitimate, but countries will actively reduce their participation or leave when they can no longer control how they conduct their foreign policy.

Additionally, though, the perception of WPON shifts dramatically because they are seen as people who can only get into those positions by having doors open for them, rather than actually being able to get them of their own merits.

That is how we win this debate. What do we stand for? We stand for the gender-blind selection of delegates. That means that countries can send whatever delegates they want. Broadly, we're very happy for the United Nations to encourage the representation of women among delegates.

Importantly and contextually, we think that, firstly, the problem isn't as great as they made it seem. There are plenty of representation of women delegates within these nations. We also tell you that generally the trend is continuing as social attitudes progress. The proposition team actually brings those attitudes backwards. But we also think they can broadly encourage that the women become, that there are more female delegates. What do we stand for in this debate then? Three main points that I'm going to bring you. Firstly, what principally delegate selection should look like. Secondly, why this massively weakens and delegitimizes these multilateral institutions. and thirdly, how this reflects poorly on women and the feminist movement as a whole. Note that most of my rebuttal will be integrated, but firstly, let's just quickly respond to their principal material about the obligation of these nations to offer them an active state. We have three key responses to this. Firstly, as we already flagged, we think it's untrue that women are always unrepresented in these organizations. In a lot of cases, they are represented. They do have a stake in the decision-making policy as delegates and also as like supporters to those delegates in like diplomatic decisions. They told us about people like Jacinda Ardern. They told us about like general social progressiveness. We think that that continues to exist. Secondly, we think this is contingent on women actually being represented where they wouldn't have otherwise. We think at the point where a majority of nations pull out rather than having a female delegate or don't like only

resentfully create that female delegate, they don't actually have any discretionary power because nations don't actually give them any of that power. Thirdly, we think all of this is predicated on the importance of women in politics. If we prove we get massive backlash towards women in politics and overall decrease their power, that obligation actually becomes more harmful. The comparison to suffrage here was completely crazy. title: Switzerland vs USA WSDC 2018 Round 3
description:
The decision in this debate was a 3-0 win for the USA. 

The motion was: This House regrets the widespread belief that motherhood is a rewarding experience.

USA Debate is the country's World Schools Debating Championship program and is sponsored by the National Speech & Debate Association. 

The coaches of the National team are Aaron and Cindi Timmons (Cindi also serves as Team Manager). 

The USA team trains for the World Championship each year at the Global Debate Symposium, held at Colorado College, in Colorado Springs, Colorado.
motion: This House believes that the societal perception of motherhood as universally rewarding does more harm than good.

argument_units.text: When my team and I were talking about this notion during prep, we realized something. Every single one of our mothers quit their job when they had us, left behind careers as teachers, flight attendants, and writers. We noticed something else. Not a single one of our fathers made the same sacrifice. The overwhelming belief that having and raising a child is universally rewarding, particularly for women, has led to a culture that shuts women out of some of the most critical opportunities in society. This culture of coercion is why we are so proud to propose. Before I introduce our first two substantive arguments with my partner, Shreyoshi DeLeverin III, I'd like to clarify some things in this round. First, that motherhood is the process of giving birth to and raising a child. Second, what exactly does it mean to regret something? We regret how this widespread belief has actually looked in history and how it has impacted society. This isn't a debate about whether motherhood is good or bad. But for them, what exactly has this expectation looked like?

This belief that motherhood is rewarding has looked like overwhelmingly positive characterizations of motherhood. It looks like things like the idea of the cult of domesticity in the early 1900s that idealized this characterization of mothers. Even divine characterizations of mothers, things like the Virgin Mary or Siddha in the Hindu religion often being identified as divine with her child. It looks like things like painting pregnancy as this glowing, beautiful experience. And, importantly, as the motion suggests, this is the overwhelming idea that parenthood is positive, focused on mothers, meaning that this expectation and this idea that parenthood is positive focused on mothers, meaning that this expectation and this idea that parenthood is super rewarding has disproportionately not at all focused on fathers, meaning the expectation to have children, an idea that this is universally rewarding, has uniquely been a burden upon women.

What do we think in this round? We wish that this expectation and idea had not existed. Let us just be clear that the comparative in this round is not a world where motherhood is demonized, or we don't recognize that there are some rewarding elements to motherhood. We regret this widespread belief that particularly for women, motherhood is overwhelmingly and universally rewarding. We prefer one where it's viewed more objectively, recognizing that there are extreme challenges, and we prefer a world with a more balanced view of fatherhood and motherhood. And we actually think there are cases where this is increasingly happening, and it is particularly in those cases where doors are being opened for women when we recognize some of the drawbacks of motherhood.

With that, let's introduce our first argument about how this exacerbates the oppression of women. Two ideas under this. The first is exacerbating institutional coercion. The belief that motherhood is overwhelmingly good has led to three things. The first is that characterizations and qualities associated with being a mother are exclusively for women. Second, they create policies to encourage women to be mothers, often at the expense of other opportunities. And third and finally, just the general expectation that women ought to be mothers above all else. And that's a responsibility uniquely for women. What has this led to institutionally? It has led to women being denied an education for much of history because they're viewed as more suited for raising children. And you don't need to know math or science or calculus or history in order to raise a child. This expectation still exists in many places where you're literally, or some women are literally shot in the head for pursuing an education in places like Afghanistan. It looks like women being shut out of politics, both institutionally, where in much of history they're just denied places in politics, but also because women see, because people see women as more suited for the home, they don't view them as being in positions of power. But finally, women are often shut out of jobs because if you're going to be a mother, and if that is such a rewarding thing for you to pursue, why would you sacrifice that experience in the name of getting a job? And even when, notably, women are allowed to get jobs, note that the first jobs that women were able to get were those that had characteristics associated with motherhood. The first jobs that women were able to get were things like being teachers or seamstresses that involved more domestic responsibilities like, I don't know, taking care of children. And this shuts out women from being able to pursue things like being a lawyer or a doctorate if they want that. The second reason this happens is through social coercion, both for young girls and for older women who are becoming mothering age. For young girls, we are told that motherhood is super rewarding and something that we should pursue from a really young age, both directly and when we're handed bride dolls and told to play house instead of doing things like playing with G.I. Joes or action figures or, you know, police action figures like boys are. And further, for older women who are approaching the age where they could be mothers, we're constantly asked, oh, when are you going to start a family? When you graduate from college, how many children do you want? These questions are almost never asked of men because society views motherhood as a rewarding experience, particularly for women. This experience is never, this expectation is never placed on men. In contrast, Barbara, if we recognize that there are a lot of costs to becoming a mother and it weren't just an exclusive expectation on women, women would be able to evaluate all of these positive and negative things and actually make this choice for themselves instead of being coercive against it. We think in a world where this belief exists, that belief takes this choice away. This is incredibly coercive and it's shut women out of a lot of society.

Now moving on to our second substantive argument, but I believe you had a point. Yes. In fact you stated that women don't evaluate this decision before having a child. However, they do evaluate whether or not they're placing the child ahead of their career, and that's when they do have a child. No, no, no. Yes. We think that women are making this evaluation, but the information that they're given when they're making this evaluation is fundamentally distorted to tell them that motherhood is overwhelmingly good and that they should pursue that above all else. If they were given more balanced information, it would be a real choice. We think it's a false one in the status quo, and that's just wrong, especially when men don't have to suffer from the same things.

Our second argument in today's round is that this leads to shaming women, both those who choose not to have children and those who do choose to become mothers. Let's start with the first one. The culture where motherhood is viewed
as overwhelmingly rewarding leads to a culture where women who choose to do things like focus on their career, like many men do, end up being seen as strange and kind backwards.
At the very least, this looks like a culture where when someone sees a woman who doesn't
have children, there's this attitude of, oh, she has no husband and family.

How sad she's missing out on all these joys of motherhood, which delegitimizes that woman's very legitimate choice. But at the worst, it looks like people thinking that these women are failing in their unique obligation to fulfill a uniquely female responsibility to have children. We think that is wrong. It is absolutely a legitimate choice for me, after I graduate from college, to be able to pursue a career and not a family, and not be shamed for doing so. Our second idea under this other argument is that it actually shames women who do in fact choose to become mothers, often coercively. We think motherhood is a really, really hard experience. Often it leads to people sacrificing their career, sacrificing time to raise their children, sacrificing sleep, particularly in early stages, having to literally clean up poop and throw up when you're raising a baby. That's really hard, when women issue these very legitimate grievances, they're seen as corrupt, bad mothers because motherhood is supposed to be this overwhelmingly positive thing.

This also leads to when women make choices that are seen as out of line with the concept of motherhood, like women who choose to balance career and family, people ask them, why aren't you at home with your children? You're being a bad mother by existing in the workplace. That is absolutely horrible. We also think that this leads to an overwhelming expectation for them to be responsible for their children's future for all of these reasons we're very proud to propose. Thank you.

title: Team Mexico (prop)  vs USA Debate (opp) World School Debating Championships 2019 - Round Eight
description:
Info Slide: Bride importing is where a man agrees to pay a woman and sponsor immigration into his country, in exchange for her agreeing to marry him.

THW ban the practice of "importing brides". 

USA Debate is the country's World Schools Debating Championship program and is sponsored by the National Speech & Debate Association. 

The coaches of the National team are Aaron and Cindi Timmons (Cindi also serves as Team Manager). 

The USA team trains for the World Championship each year at the Global Debate Symposium, held at Colorado College, in Colorado Springs, Colorado.
motion: This house would ban the importation of brides.

title: Hong Kong (prop) vs USA (opp) - WSDC 2019 -
description:
In art and popular culture, THBT creating new lead characters for minorities (eg Hancock, Black Panther is better than recasting them in existing roles already played by other actors/communities (eg Ghostbusters, The Little Mermaid).

USA Debate is the country's World Schools Debating Championship program and is sponsored by the National Speech & Debate Association. 

The coaches of the National team are Aaron and Cindi Timmons (Cindi also serves as Team Manager). 

The USA team trains for the World Championship each year at the Global Debate Symposium, held at Colorado College, in Colorado Springs, Colorado.
motion: This house supports the creation of new minority characters over the recasting of existing characters with minority actors.

argument_units.text: The fight for equality begins as a fight to be yourself and not to be someone else. Not to live in the shadow, but to be yourself as the individual.

We think that is a world that we would rather not support.

Second of all, why the discourse that you produce is inherently counterproductive through recasting, and why we're better on our side. Before I move into that, some basic definitions. We define art and pop culture as generally entertainment that's created for either self-expression or sending a message. We think this oftentimes means mass media. We're talking about things all the way from movies to plays sorts of viewed art, because we're talking purely about actors. title: Vietnam WSDC 2023 Semi Finals - Malaysia vs USA
description:
#debate #WSDC #WSDC2023
Malaysia vs USA / Semi Finals / Vietnam WSDC 2023
Proposition: Malaysia
Opposition: USA
Info Slide: A typical nuclear family is composed of two partners with children. In some countries a significant and vocal part of the LGBTQ+ movement are actively advocating settling down and forming nuclear families.
Motion:
This House believes that the LGBTQ+ community should actively embrace the nuclear family ideal

Opp won

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLAntmD_yHPRCPBuUVQujKcdczKF8ccSgn
motion: This house supports the LGBTQ movement actively embracing the nuclear family ideal.

argument_units.text: Being a parent is the most rewarding thing many people can hope for. It is a desire to watch your child grow from a baby who speaks to the world semifinals, for example. Queer people are no different from that. But we think uniquely under the side of proposition where their choice to have a family is empowered and when they're normalized in the status quo, that is a world we yearn for. We're so proud to propose.

Before I forward two substantive arguments within the speech, on to set up four things. One, we support the LGBTQ movement actively embracing the nuclear family ideal. What does this look like? It means that they embrace the concept that LGBTQ individuals are capable of having a nuclear family. Note that this is quite similar to what the LGBTQ movement did with the free love movement when it came to doing things like trying to co-opt marriage equality for queer individuals. B, we think the messaging the movement would then adopt is they would advocate for the legitimisation of LGBTQ individuals being able to do things like have a family. So they focus on creating accessibility pathways, for example, making it far easier for queer individuals to adopt a child or have a biological one through IVF. Secondly, note that there are many iterations of what the nuclear family ideal looks like. So at this precipice in the debate, we think the LGBTQ movement would frame the ideal through the lens of queerness. For example, having the ability to have a family isn't only restricted to heterosexual individuals. But note that this doesn't mean that the community will have to advocate only for family at the expense of other things. We think they can still do it. We think they can still advocate for queer individuals having access to things like marriage. It doesn't have to be exclusively family.

On our side, we would do things like focus on dismantling the stereotypes surrounding queer individuals and their ability to have a family. For example, that having a mother and father isn't necessary in order to raise a child successfully, queer individuals can do this too. Thirdly, what is the actual comparative that opposition needs to defend in this debate? Note that in the context of the status quo, we've already been able to secure things like marriage rights for queer individuals in many liberal democracies, but the one stereotype that we have yet to defeat in the status quo is the notion that LGBTQ individuals are incapable of having a family because they're going to corrupt our children. Note that the stance of having a nuclear family isn't one that exists in a vacuum. It is a lifestyle choice that the movement is going to prescribe onto individuals. Therefore, on the side of opposition, they also need to prescribe an alternate ideal lifestyle for LGBTQ individuals to pursue. Note then on our burden. Insofar as we prove that, them choosing to co-opt a nuclear family ideal is able to empower the ability of LGBTQ individuals to pursue a family and uniquely dismantles the harmful stereotypes that are imposed onto them in the status quo, that is enough to take this round. Two arguments. One, on how the adoption of a queer family model is the best form towards humanising members of the queer community. And secondly, while we maximise the choice of members in the community to have access to things like family planning.

On the first argument, three parts. One, note that the adoption of the family unit for many social movements has actually been an extremely strategic move, because a vast majority of the social movements in the status quo were successful largely because they chose to integrate the family unit into their models of hypocrisy. For example, the civil rights movement saying that all individuals, regardless of race, should have the ability to do things like have children. Or the feminist movement choosing to co-opt the nuclear family to show that working women are able to simultaneously hold a job and raise a successful family. What this means is that every social movement to an extent in the status quo recognises that society is built upon the family unit, and we believe that the LGBTQ movement participating in this trend is crucial towards their success. What is the conclusion of this layer? One, it shows that the concept of the nuclear family model is malleable and it's susceptible to evolution, so it isn't a stagnant one that opposition would likely try to argue to you. But secondly, past precedent shows that other movements have been largely successful when they choose to adopt this model, because what you're doing is you're trying to show the rest of society that we can be the same as you, and we are not as different as you think you are. Secondly, why is this trend of co-opting the family unit actually beneficial against fighting stereotypes? Because note, the biggest stereotype that queer individuals face in the status quo is that you are incompatible with the quote-unquote normal ways of life, that you are unable to exist as a functional member of society because your sexuality is different from the rest of them. The way you combat this is by humanising them. So how exactly does embracing the family unit humanise these individuals? Two ways. One, we do things like spotlight the very human experiences of queer families when it comes to raising their children. For example, through shows like Modern Family, which show Mitch and Cam who are able to successfully raise their adopted daughter Lily, and the parallel once again is the free love movement, where we showed that all individuals deserve the ability to love whoever they want, and that was highly successful when it came to garnering things like marriage equality. But secondly, and more importantly, note that society's greatest respect is reserved for parents. Because uniquely, parenting is something that requires large amounts of sacrifice. It's difficult. And when we show that queer individuals are able to be good parents, we think this respect is cross-applied to LGBTQ individuals, because society can empathize with them with how difficult it is when it comes to raising a child. And the way we overcome these differences is by showing that our interests are aligned. Why are we able to do this? Because now we think that the notion is that these individuals are just like me and they deserve my respect. For example, Pete Buttigieg, who's not only a politician, is also capable of being a father. I think these are the instances of humanization that we think are good. Lastly then, on impacting, what are the two stereotypes we dispel? One, that these individuals are not capable of being selfless, because when we show that parenting is extremely difficult effort, it takes plenty of positive perceptions that are now attached to these individuals. And the parallel is that politicians who don't have families in the status quo are criticized as incapable because they can't even control their home. Literally every single successful politician has to have proven their capability via having a successful family. But secondly, and more importantly, we remove the gender stereotypes of maternalism and paternalism that exist in families. Because what we show now is that queer relationships can be diverse, that a family can sustain without having a maternal or paternal figure, and that both parents are capable of offering things like emotional compensation to their child. Before I go on, sure. Modern-day feminism and other social movements reject nuclear families as it confines people to static boundaries of being the breadwinner or the caretaker. Why should the LGBTQ movement then adopt this despite the rejection by parallel social movements? So, one, that's not true. I would argue that feminism, the only reason why we're advocating against the nuclear family unit is because it does things like say that women only have to have things like children. But uniquely on our side, the counter-narrative that we are pushing is that LGBTQ individuals don't deserve the right to have a family. Uniquely, when we dispel the stereotype that they are capable human beings, that is when we actually maximize choice.

Second argument on how we maximize the ability of members to have access to things like family planning. The preamble of this argument is that the purpose of the LGBTQ movement has always been to empower all choices. Three ways. One, not that society has historically disempowered LGBTQ individuals from having a family. Not only have they faced multiple hurdles in terms of the aforementioned stereotypes in the first argument, but the greatest injustice you could impose onto these individuals is that when they cannot access their right to have a family, why absent of this emphasis, you won't be able to get it on their side? One, the movement isn't going to concentrate resources on creating accessibility pathways. So sure, there'll still be queer individuals who want to have children, but these are only the most wealthy who can afford the high cost of IVF. Because the narrative that queer people are compatible with the nuclear family unit is precisely what lets you advocate for the support structures that enable them to safely start families, like IVF or adoption centres. I think it's the prerequisite to opening up choice, which responds to the seventh minute on org about why it's hard to have a child. I'm saying that embracing the nuclear family is what creates the platform for you to want to have that child. And this is important, because if you agree that these people are going to otherwise suffer, they really want to have a child because it's so important for their self-actualization. We create the pathway for them to get that point. It doesn't exist on their side. Their only response is this trades away resources from other predictions. This is just ridiculous. So we should just define all queer art because it's seen as less valuable. We should abandon protests to have trans people in the military because it only affects a small group of people? What we explain is that it's an important issue, so we should put resources into it, even if there are other considerations they should make, that is just non-comparative. Secondly, we explain it's actually easier to campaign for family support because family is glorified, because it's seen as intersectional with other movements, like supporting Planned Parenthood welfare, it becomes easier for us to get these legislative protections on our side or the forms of social acceptance that are on their side. So at the end of this clash, they don't actually have any exclusive harm or benefits in this debate. Our third substantive expands on this excellently by explaining that, even if it wasn't direct material alleviation, it was through media representation that empowers queer people. Within pop culture, we pivot away from homogenized portrayals of queer people in movies as the eccentric character or someone who's the Mary Sue by showing that why within these families, there are someone who's core, someone that can be lovable, and someone which you are humanized with. At the end of this debate, we proved two very simple things that means we make it to the finals. First, we're able to explain why these parents are better able to have those children there, but two, why these people are able to get rid of the worst stereotypes that currently hold down the queer community.

It's only our proposition to enable this change. Thank you. Honestly, Team USA was disappointed when Team Malaysia decided that this debate would be about we have to defend gay people never have families and they get to defend that they always have access to families. I want to start this speech by really stepping into reality and talking about what this debate is actually about. Their side of the house needed to prove to you an overvailing narrative that told people nuclear families were something you ought to have, something that we should idolize, something that spurred all the change they wanted on their side of the house. Let's be very reasonable panel. Our side never needed to defend that these people could not have families. They themselves characterized you in first that in a vast majority of cases people could already have families when they chose to. That marriage laws across the world made it so that people could access these familial units. What then was the difference between the two sides? Because Team Malaysia, you guys getting up here for the entirety of the debate and trying to say we don't support families was not sufficient argumentation. The reality was this. Our role is one in which you got advocacy for immediate needs, that you still have things like access to gay marriage, but you've got support for the choices of LGBTQ people. Their side of the house had to defend an adoption of the norm, a norm that a nuclear family was viable. The second thing I want to do just at the top of this speech is point out a contradiction. Last Peeker says we didn't have to support the nuclear family narrative as it exists today or the specific iteration of it, but then they go on to say about why this narrative is such a good thing. Guys, if you think the nuclear family narrative is so problematic, then why are you supporting it on your side? Presumably you would also rather support a world where people had the agency to commit free choice, that we supported things like people's liberation and didn't antagonize people for settling down.

This proposition was just very uncharitable in this debate and didn't actually engage with the two comparative. I want to ask two questions then in this speech. Number one, who gets support for the LGBTQ plus movement? And second, who actually got better outcomes in this debate? First question then is on who gets support for the LGBTQ movement. I want to first talk about this in terms of stakeholders. Proposition banks most of their case on people who want children, people who actively want to have a family on their side of the house. I have a couple of things to say. Number one, I think you can use your own framing and characterization in the round against them in this regard, that if most people accepted that people should be together, the choice did exist where they wanted it to. So this applied in the most socially progressive

societies, and you did get access to a nuclear family if you wanted to opt into it. This is very, very clear. But second, our arguments operated in the vast majority of societies where support was not stringent, where people did not like the idea of people existing in families. And to this we forwarded many arguments.

Team Malaysia just keeps saying that we need to defend people who don't have families, but they actually didn't engage with any of our arguments. The first push we heard was on fractionalization, that when you were induced to the idea of a nuclear family, and when this is something the movement necessarily pushed for, the adoption came with a trade-off. In order for the LGBTQ movement to substantially push for change and to encourage people that this idea of a nuclear family was good, it came at the expense of ideas like liberation. It came at the expense of the idea that you could spend the rest of your life or take the first dozen years of your life to figure out who you are. You could explore your sexual identity. The idea of a nuclear family was diametrically opposed to these things. They could not just get up here and say, oh, we get this too on their side of the house, because the adoption of a norm, what this looked like when people were giving speeches about having a nuclear family and how it was so good to be a gay person and a familial unit, all of those things necessarily came with a trade-off. And that alienated people. In movements all across the world where support for LGBTQ people was already in the vast minority, you needed the person who was asexual or didn't have romantic preferences to buy into your movement because then you galvanized collective change that uplifted everyone. This was a much more reasonable comparative, and it's way too late for proposition-reply to actually respond to the arguments you heard and the round.

But second, we told you about how this was likely to immediately alienate people, that look, the wash in this debate was societies where we already had this acceptance. But the change then was that you threatened one thing that people felt was closest, that the idea of the nuclear family was so enshrined in conservatism, which they concede to you themselves, and that necessarily meant that people felt aggravated and threatened when you also tried to adopt this idea of a nuclear family, that they felt threatened and were not likely to open reforms, that they immediately shut down. They hated the idea that people were overstepping on the nuclear family that they believed righteously belonged to them. So all of this meant that their arguments in this round were applicable to the vast minority of people, the places where nuclear families and the choice already exist, but our arguments catered to the vast majority. It is way too late again for Proposition to Reply to come to this. The last piece of material then I want to forward to you is this idea of elitism. They try to say that, ah, we make things less expensive on our side of the house, but this is not really the reason why things like IVF were so expensive. It was because companies knew it was an inelastic good and that people would pay anything to have access to those things, and they were able to use this monopoly power to create high prices. Their side of the house, maybe if they get a little bit more support of that, is knived by the fractionalization that occurs when they feel like the only way for the LGBTQ movement to go forward is to regressress because they concede this. The nuclear family is an outdated idea of how society runs, so why on earth proposition would you insist that everyone go to revert to it? I have no idea. Before I talk about the second clash on better outcomes. If conservatives are so uncompromising and will antagonize every deviation from the patriarchal nuclear family, how does a queer couple in an area where queer marriage is legalized opt into a family? I think that on your side of the house, you get more antagonization. I just explained to you that people feel like the thing they value the most, the nuclear family, is being stripped of them to begin with. This is why you preferred our counterfactual, where we did not set the bar as so high as to try and take a nuclear family, but pushed for gradualism, that you could still get access to things like equality in the workplace for LGBTQ people, but you did not need to insist on this primary doctrine that dictated the language and the rhetoric of the movement on your side of the house.

Who then gets better outcomes? I want to talk about a crucial stakeholder in this debate that I think they just brush over, the idea that not all members of the LGBTQ community bought into this idea of the nuclear family. Their only response to this is to say, ah, but when we advocated for equality and gay marriage, those people didn't necessarily feel alienated. But our response is quite simple. The act of embracement was a question of the lifestyle of those individuals and insisted that there was only one way you ought to live and one presiding paradigm. It was not about choice. This was different from things like marriage. It was about the one way you ought to live and one presiding paradigm. It was not about choice. This was different from things like marriage. It was about the only way you ought to live your life is this very specific prescription on their side of the house. It was antagonistic to things like liberalization, whereas existing in some sort of marriage was not. This was the difference on our side of the house. This meant then you got more alienation of those groups and you got less propensity for change But secondly we think you've got less solidarity with things for other movements. In response to a POI we give in their first they say ah the feminist movement like embraces nuclear families. Guys, that's just not true Feminism and fourth-weight feminism today is diametrically opposed to those ideas So in this regard we think it was a reversion of norms for the LGBTQ community to go back to adopt a nuclear family when their other, sister movements were harming it, which meant you got less buy-in from constituent and neighbouring social movements on our side of the house, and you got less ability, rather, to mobilise the change you so needed. There was a trade-off in this debate, but Proposition just wanted to try and back us into a corner and say people did not need to have families.

Guys, it's so clearly unreasonable. The real change in this debate then was if it was true you got sweeping policy changes on their side of the house which we explained to you are unlikely to change then presumably this narrative had some coercive coercive application to begin with. Presumably it told people that there is one way you ought to live your life. The strategic mistake of Team Malaysia was to keep capitalizing on a narrative that was unreasonable and untrue. We were true to the heart of the motion, that if it was true they wanted their benefits, they needed to take a hard stance. We took the hard stance in this debate, embracing a nuclear family ideal which was outdated, ahistoric, and harmed all individuals in the movement that was directly antagonistic to the progressive movement of the LGBTQ movement was going to yield harm for all. It is a clear opposition ballot.
Thank you. Now, for the reply speaker, we may be turned to have the author reply speaker deliver a speech not repeating form in a 15-minute period.

Alright, is everyone good? Side Proposition's entire case is based on a logical jump. And that jump is that when the queer community embraces nuclear family, that they'll get access to the institutions of a nuclear family, they'll access things like cheaper IVF and things like adoption. This is not a logical jump that I think you as a panel should let them run away with.

Because in order for them to get all their practical benefits, This is not a logical jump that I think you as a panel should let them run away with. Because in order for them to get all their practical benefits, they had to prove that governments and society at large would change. And it's because they haven't proved that, and they haven't answered our five, six different mechanisms of analysis to how they don't get that, why they lose the debate.

Two key clashes. The first clash is about buy-in. This is the most important clash in the round. And I want to talk about three stakeholders about buy-in. This is the most important clash in the round. And I want to talk about three stakeholders under buy-in. The first stakeholder are people that are conservative or generally in the status quo don't like gay people. I want to note, this is the only stakeholder that they get a delta of change on their side of the house. We told you that conservatives were unlikely to budge. They had fundamental religious and ideological objections to the existence of gay people. And no matter how many times they watched Kim's Convenience or Modern Family, it would not change these deep-rooted beliefs that were ingrained and indoctrinated in them and perpetuated through societies for decades and decades. But we also gave you other reasons that weren't properly engaged with from side proposition. There was a level of competition of resource that existed between getting things like adoption and getting things like tax incentives, and that if more gay people were accessing things like nuclear families, it would take you out. We also told you that marriage and adoption are viewed as being something that are sanctions and sanctioned by religions. And when people enter those kind of fields, again, people are likely to feel threatened.

There are two takeaways you have. Number one, they don't get those people jumping to the side of supporting LGBTQ plus movements. And number two, you're more likely to have retaliation and backlash. What were the two stakeholders that we told you about that didn't get proper engagement? First of all, was people that were inside of the LGBTQ plus community themselves. And we give you structural reasons why most of these people did not want this idea of a nuclear marriage. That for years and years they were repressed by their parents that were telling them that you need to settle down with a good boy or a good girl and bring me kids.

The people that were in the LGBTQ plus movement were trying to escape that narrative and escape that societal repression. And what they did on their side of the house is that you made the movement adopt that societal repression.

That was likely to be very, very divisive. The most fundamental core of the LGBTQ plus movement was likely to lead. But the final mechanism were people that were outside of the movement. These people were likely to be incredibly progressive because that allows them to align with the LGBTQ plus movement. And we told you that the nuclear family ideal was sexist and patriarchal, that it was oppositional to things like the feminist movement, that in the fourth wave advocated for the liberation of women and the accessing of things like career opportunities. And you needed external actors because the bottom line is that in most countries, the gay community was very, very small and they relied on the support of buy-in of external stakeholders to get policy and change. This outweighed their case on two levels. First of all, it was on a prerequisite. They never got broad-based supports for marriage if they never got buy-in from their own community. But second of all, it was on severity. That the more immediate needs that gay people face, like workplace harassment, like hate crimes, never get addressed, and those things were going to lead to more tangible change than not getting a marriage.

The second thing I want to talk about is how this harms individuals. And my opponents already concede that this was likely to be a coercive norm, that it was going to enter things like media, and it was likely going to be the priority for things like financing. And the reason why coercion was so bad was because it prevented people from enjoying their lives. It structurally alienated people that were asexual or pansexual and didn't fit into the strict structures of nuclear families. It limited people's exploration because marriage had very, very high sunk costs and it prevents you from having the kind of flexibility to explore your identity. This was crucial to the queer experience. And finally, it was just very, very damn expensive to do something like a marriage and raise children.

We told you that the nuclear family was never going to adapt. This is a narrative that exists for thousands and thousands of years. This is a narrative that is strict labor rules. The only way that they get access to their arguments about humanization is if they buy into the kind of strict, rigid nuclear family that is so problematic. On buy-in, on individuals, we win. It is a clear opposition ballot. Thank you. Now, Jan, what's fantastic for me is that we have the proposition of life in terms of .

If watching the most human facets of a queer individual, the most selfless, the most loving aspects of them, couldn't convince homophobes, then putting them into a capitalist system through a system of quota, forcing them to work in workplace quotas, would ultimately result in far worse outcomes under opposition.

This debate had to exist in a world where the queer community had some power, not just that on our side of the house, queer community was utterly demonized, and on their side, they're going to institute strict workplace quota for workplace integration,

and somehow they will succeed. Two things in this speech. Firstly, on the diversity of the queer community, and therefore we are coercive, says opposition. Two responses. One, all of their analysis on settling down, on marriages being hard to escape from, from preventing sexual freedom or whatever, are all contingent on marriage, not on a nuclear family. Insofar as the queer movement has historically supported queer marriage, opposition can't run away by saying, you know what, we don't actually care. But the response

of the POI in third is damning because they will only oppose the sweeping reforms, like marriage, if the legalization of queer marriage comes at the expense of other policies, which means it's not about the immediate inclusion of people within the community, it's about objective legislative outcomes. Then all we have to prove is that we can legalize IVF

and have anti-discrimination bills, and that is a concession that the coerciveness of the movement does not matter and is irrelevant to this debate. But secondly, the misunderstanding of our case runs rampant throughout their bench, a misunderstanding of what policies encompass. Opposition replies says that doesn't mean you get access to systems of nuclear family.

That's literally our first argument about giving you access to the system of nuclear family. Then third proposition then third opposition says it's going to be coercive because there are policies. Policies are not inherently coercive. We told you about policies that empower choice in a society that was coercive, no response.

Two things then. Firstly, on harming politically advocacy. I think this entire issue is contingent on how people are going to react to the queer nuclear family, and their case of change also relies upon some degree of humanization. Insofar as we prove that our humanization is the most effective, that is how you're able to overcome stereotypes. You only believe it's a sin because you believe that queer individuals have horrible morals, but when you see them loving and caring for the child, then it gets rid of the stereotype that they are selfish, that they don't care. Three things. One, about backlash. How do you think any movement ever got any change? If people were so homophobic, does opposition really believe that the moment you say, let's have queer marriage, thereby encroaching on the sanctity of marriage, people are like, oh, that's fine. At least you don't touch the children, right?

Our mechanism for critical mass, in fact, was threefold. One, we told you about platforming successful stories, stories that on opposition would not exist because we told you about structures that never existed. Secondly, because of shaping parental perceptions. Like the feminist movement, they were not opposed to family because they empowered motherhood. They were opposed to the patriarchal norms of nuclear family. We can then be opposed to the homophobic norms of patriarchal family, and that is how families evolve over time. That is the reason why women are allowed to work and still have families, because things are allowed to evolve. But thirdly, on shared history, historically children are the very thing that connects all individuals when it comes to the love is free, it is about making common ground that opposition eviscerates.

Secondly, we think the humanisation on our side is unique, because we equate the labour of love for parenting with queer individuals, with a framework that straight individuals are familiar with. What opposition has to defend is a world that never touches the idea of a nuclear family. By embracing it, we are able to show alternative mechanisms of somebody who could still love their children. The impact is simple. It's not just IVF. It is about stopping the demonization of queer families who are told by the movement that they are conforming to heteronormativity and are not allowed to access families.

What oppression symmetrically exists perhaps, but the most urgent issue is homophobia and opposition can't make an arbitrary distinction on what they believe to be more important. Price is of no issue for somebody who wants to have a child. Opposition doesn't get to decide that. Under a system of homophobia, any choice is liberation, and perhaps the ballot then is clearer for proposition. Thank you to both teams for what was an excellent semis.

title: WSDC 2017 - Round 3 - Team Canada vs Team Wales - Women in Religious Institutions
description:
World Schools Debating Championships 2017 in Bali, Indonesia. 

Round 3

Motion: This house would remove tax-exempt status from religious organisations that refuse to appoint female leaders.

Proposition: Team Wales 

Opposition: Team Canada

This motion was pre-prepared. 

Team Wales won the debate on a 3-0 decision.
motion: This house would remove tax-exempt status from religious organisations that refuse to appoint female leaders.

argument_units.text: A doctrine that says that women cannot be is nothing less than slander, but just on half of the women race, but on all of the women race. That's why Team Rose is proud to stand for the team line that we will not grant privilege and favour to those who willfully slander women.

What are we proposing? A five-part model. Firstly, organisations who wish to keep their statutory status should appoint a large number of female leaders reasonably quickly at every level of their hierarchies. And obviously we would not be happy with just one or two token candidates. Secondly, insofar as we get tax revenue from this policy, the money will be spent disproportionately to help women and will also be part of the international aid budget. Thirdly, given that international policy requires a reasonably sophisticated tax code and state apparatus. We would imagine that this happens in primarily Western liberal democracies. But we say that our principles apply in any country in which opposition can prove to us that such tax codes exist. Fourthly, this debate presumes that the state and the religion are separate, so it does not occur in democracies like Saudi Arabia or Iran, but it does in secular states like India, South Africa and most of Europe. Fifthly, we realise that some of these institutions carry out genuine charitable activities and we support this. So we will therefore make all charitable activities tax deductible, just as we allow charitable work by corporations to be deductible. Just to be clear however, we will ensure that these activities are genuinely charitable, so things like missionary work do not apply. However, full day and exercise such things would. Let's be clear, these normalizations would still be tied to property, assets, investments and income.

So we bring you a three part case. Firstly, I will explain to you why tax exemption is a privilege and not a right. Secondly, I will tell you how we get more female leaders from the R7 House. And lastly, my second speaker will be talking on how we

empower women all across the globe. On to my first argument. Why tax exemption is a privilege and not a right. We think it is high time to update the RK policies with the favour of religion in order to reflect more modern values of equality. We believe that the government should have every right to tax women's coordination pursued precisely through the first view on the principle of reciprocity. Religious institutions could not exist without the support continually provided to them by the government. They could not hold poverty if the government did not hold up the law and the police force which we all pay for. More importantly, they could not exist without the right to free association, speech and freedom of religion, which is upheld by the police and the judiciary, which, once again, we all pay for. It is abhorrent that religions can derive such benefit from the taxes we pay and the laws which we uphold, and they do not contribute their fair share to upholding them. Secondly, as long as religions don't pay tax, the burden on ordinary people is dramatically increased. The general population pays for the billions of dollars of government spending, and whilst some of this burden falls on the wealthy, a lot of it does fall on ordinary, wealthy-class people, the poor and women. In our world, it becomes possible to alleviate this burden when religions pay fair taxes. Team Canada will leave poor women to make up for the greed of religions. So, to be clear, the premise of this debate is that religions owe an enormous debt to society and to the government and should have been paying taxes for it very long time. However, just as the government has taken it away, so too can the government forgive. With this, it could be reasonable for the government to forgive this debt if the religion helps it to promote certain policies. In the same way, crediting by forgiven debt is the debt of the enemy. However, it is reasonable for the government to forgive the debt of religions, since those religions help to promote certain useful policies. What we propose is to do something of a deal with religious organizations that is unprecedented for such deals. We already give Times Square this to corporations who promote affirmative action in the second or combat climate change. We will forgive the debt of religions which promote female leaders. That's what we stand for.
Do you believe that the role of men in religious institutions is more important than the role that women play?
We don't think men are more important than women in religion. We think that religions have been explicitly stated that men should move how women,

or should be part of the government in religious institutions. Therefore, we think that religious institutions have an equal playing field, have an equal ground. That's what we stand for. heroes. Now onto our second question. So it's time to know, why is policy resolved in the appointment of more women? Firstly, how does our membership incentivize change within doctrines? Let's outline in my example the money involved here will be a sufficient incentive for change within the religion. Note that this is an extremely large sum of money that we're talking about. It would impact religious institutions both on a small and on a large scale. On a large scale, when the Catholic Church has to pay tax on the CC channel, when it has to pay property tax on trying real-estate materials in every major city in Europe, the church that currently exists will not be financially viable, as any reserved religious organization would not be able to exist as it currently does. In addition, we imagine that for most religious leaders, the thought of losing their jobs, their buildings, and other pet projects they've been working on for a long period of time will be a sufficient incentive for them to change their policy. Furthermore, we think that on a smaller scale, with independence laws and smaller congregations, they will also come by without policy. We imagine that it is most likely also that for inferior leaders, that will close down entirely, as would be the case given that they will die of small donations and tax exemptions too. Furthermore, we think this incentive would also speak to particularly hardline and devout leaders within the movement. Why have that aspect? Because every program that a hardline leader wants to promote still requires money. Launching new missionary efforts, converting new funders, or introducing new education programs in order to save souls, these things all require money. You see, no reason why they would prioritize not appointing female leaders over anything other than a bit of their doctrine. In addition, we think this is especially true given that we imagine that at least some religious organizations will have a private policy and will then keep their money and their missionary benefits. Given that happens, any church where you please honor that we refuse to comply, this is being outcompeted and losing followers as a result. Now, we think that this policy, this chain, will be fairly easy for leaders to make within their religions. Why? Two precisely. Firstly, if a religious leader was to introduce a policy, even if they are doing so for purely financial motives, it is very easy for them to claim that they are doing it for genuine doctrinal reasons. That's why when Pope Francis wanted to soften the church's stance on homosexuality, he was able to back himself up by claiming that the Bible already supported him. The Jew on Jesus' son on the mountain said, if a man is gay and loves God, who am I to judge him? Thus he justified an entirely new policy with reference to old, already existing doctrine. Can you imagine something similar would happen when appointed human leaders. He perhaps would quote Jesus' words, but the person with the most knowledge should be the leader, or any other thing of sorts. This is especially easy given that religion can be very contradictory, and leaders can choose the interpretation that most believers get pregnant with women in order to prepare for the equality, while still adhering to their religion. The second reason why this change will be easy to make. There are men inside a school who want to change doctrine. Who want to change doctrine. This is for two reasons. Firstly, they want more confidence. They will get back if they incorporate other values into their religion. And secondly, they live in a modern world, they absorb modern media, and the idea of female leaders is just by no means a thing. And this means that there are people who exist who want to change doctrine. There is no less resistance for them to do so. But, we'll thank you furthermore and lastly why is it that this change would be accepted by members of these individual organizations for comprehensive reasons firstly it is the nature of religious leaders that the court was deferred to them because they think they come from a place of higher purpose and they represent something bigger than the individual religious leaders commonly affect politics in a community they have dinner people's, have the power to win hearts and minds, panel. And as such, they are trustworthy and essential parts of communities. Secondly, when women show charisma, knowledge, and dedication, the men who oppose their curriculum will come to respect them and learn that they should respect women in the more general sense. Thirdly, with generations, what now seems to be radical ideas become far more accepted, and what we see is that this resentment is going to naturally cease to exist with time. Fourthly and finally, it is just not true that women take no leadership roles in these communities to begin with. There is to an extent no female leadership, and it was our policy to build on that. That's why in the Indian Tunchayak, the community councils, that is, women routinely take leadership roles. If conservatives can accept women on village councils, they can certainly get used to female priests. Part of it for all these reasons, and because we refuse to grant privilege to those who willfully slander women, we are very proud to propose.

Freedom of religion is paramount to a civil society which maximizes the rights of its citizens. For that reason, the threshold which the government must adhere to intervene against freedom of religion is extremely high.

Proposition must prove three things, and all three things, to cross the threshold of a justified intervention. They must prove, A, that there is a pressing and substantial problem for the government to alleviate. B, proposition-specific model for intervention is the only way to solve this problem c The intervention will do more measurable good than harm

Today, Team Canada's case will demonstrate that it is impossible for Team Wales to meet these burdens given the genuine characterization of a religious institution which Team Wales has conveniently missed out on. We're going to do this through three constructive contentions. I'm going to tell you firstly about the freedom of faith, and then a broader conception of real empowerment. My partner, Armand's second speech, no thank you, is going to give you a point about the servants of God and the public. But first,

reputation. I want to start with the model that Team Wales brought us. The first idea they gave us is that they're going to require religious institutions to appoint a large number of women, they're going to require them to appoint them quickly, and they're going to require them to appoint them at all levels. We have a few questions about that, because that actually was sort of vague when you get down to it, right? What is the timeline? How many women need to be appointed? When it comes to the formalities of the tax code, Team Wales needs to have those answers. We'd also ask you, does a woman need to be the pope? Really, how consistent are they going to be with, of course, forceifying all levels of leadership happening? Another question, would they consider the mother superior of a covenant of nuns to be a female religious leader? We ask you secondly, what if women genuinely believe that their role in the religious structure is not to be a formalized leader? What happens in Team Wales' world when no women volunteer themselves up for this position? In terms of their argumentation, they told us that taxation is the right product for religion. We told you that society can also benefit from religion the way that religion benefits from society, and that's why we've negated the obligation to tax like we do with charitable institutions. And if it's true that they're so principally required to pay their taxes, why are they willing to present an exemption if they comply? The only reason is that they actually don't want to separate the church and state. They want to use the church as an arm of the government to promote their politically subjective doctrine. I think this is really tense with the model they brought. We gave you a POI on the roles of men and women in the religious institutions and whether or not they thought they were equal. They gave you a sort of evasive answer in which they said, we want equality, which we know, under the status quo, they don't think the roles of men and women are equal within the religious framework. This means two things. Firstly, it's tense with their concession that women have existing power and existing roles. The first narrative that we get is that these religions are so oppressive towards women, the government needs to intervene to protect them from discrimination. The impacts of poor communities losing out on essential services. I have no idea what the world of proposition looks like by the end of this debate. That being said, two areas clash. Firstly, on the principle. The major claim that we get at the top of PROC is that religions are only able to exist because of services from the state, giving them a privilege is unfair.
