title: WSDC 2018 R3: India vs Estonia
description:
R3: "This House regrets the widespread belief that motherhood is a rewarding experience."

India PROP vs Estonia OPP

3:0 India won
motion: This house regrets the glorification of motherhood.

argument_units.text: She finished it with a first class in her college. Two years later, she was made to marry. And three years later, I was born.

This is no debate. This is no new debate. It's something we've been fighting in places like India, in places like Sri Lanka, across the developing world, where the pressure to get married is a pressure that takes away from women's choices, from the ability to empower themselves.

The belief that women have to get meaning from their motherhood gives birth to an egregious burden that in India it checks. What do we stand for? When we describe this glorification or this norm and belief that motherhood is a rewarding experience, what does that look like? It looks like an ubiquitous social norm where women's lives are told to get meaning from motherhood, which glorifies sacrifice, calls it something that's beautiful that women have to make. It's also something that others believe in,

that families believe in, that your parents believe in, that your siblings believe in, that society have to make. It's also something that others believe in, that families believe in, that your parents believe in, that your siblings believe in, that society believes in that. Where women grow up, where they're born as girls, and they're given to other children as dogs to play with. Where there's an expectation from employers, from family members, that you'll get married and have a child. Where mothers' lives are told

to be good if they're only devoted to their children. that a good mother is someone who spends their time running around their child. Remember that this is not a debate about generally parenting being notified, because it's the kind of burden that's placed uniquely on women. For men, the question often is, what are you going to be when you grow up? For women, are you going to be a mother, or do you want to have a carrier that's something in their children? What would the world have looked like in the absence of such a narrative? In the absence of pressure, it looks like the absence of pressure to deny meaning from having a child. Where choices are based often on personal preferences rather than pressures that are based on you by the people around you. We're not saying that motherhood is bad. We're just saying that we shouldn't automatically assume that it is something that's a part of every woman's life and push them towards it. So two things that I'm going to tell you that uniquely derive from motherhood, which is the reason why we regret this. First, women's choices. Second, the kind of burdens that

they have to take. And second, we're just going to talk about women without children and how the norms around this hurt specific vulnerable groups amidst women. First argument, motherhood removes women's control over their own selves. Three ways in which women's choices are hurt. Information, the choice to enter motherhood, and the ability to leave. First, on information. Glorification of motherhood is responsible for the lack of information about it. When it crowds out other information, right? When you don't know what kinds of pain pregnancy induces. when you don't know post-mortem depression even exists, where women feel incredibly depressed after they've given delivery, when many women don't even know when they're on the delivery bed that women often defecate during the process of delivery. But also, you don't know about the long term. You don't know that it's going to suck out all your time, your money and place an incredible familial burden on you. But why is motherhood the glorification of this non-responsible for it? Because you grow up with the idea that this is something you have to do. You never seek out information. You're told you don't need this information when this is just something that's automatically assigned to you based on the sex that you were

born into. But often this information doesn't exist. When the kinds of family and parents that you talk to never want to talk about this. They just want to tell you how beautiful it is to be a mother. How incredible it feels when your child goes to her first day in school. How incredible it feels when your child does this, when your child does that, but never what it looks like for you. But second, the choice to enter is imaginary. It starts at birth when you're born as a girl child. The kinds of dolls you get are dolls of children asking you to take care of them. When you're asked constantly when you're getting married, when you go to little girls as uncles in Indian weddings and ask them, oh, when do you want to get married? Or who do you want to marry? What kind of a child do you want to grow up? When it invests itself in tangible things, when literally parents across spaces like Shrilankar Vandesh give their girl children a humanities education as opposed to a STEM education because that just perfectly sets them up for that marriage. When there's a familial and societal pressure, right? Because you save up for marriage if it's a girl child and you save up for college if it's a boy child. It's not just that that the narrative often is overwhelming, often becomes an external pressure, but that it physically limits your choice. It physically limits your choice when you quit your career at a crucial age because you can't go back to developing it. It physically limits your choice when your parents give you a specific kind of education because that's

what's best suited for motherhood. This is something again we see across the developing world. Something that's just so overwhelming. Something that's investing itself in every woman's life. And we think that's just disgusting. What about it? It's self-perpetuating. Mothers raise their own girls like this. That if this debate is about children, it's about the little girls who are told this from when they grow up. Because boys get the Power Ranger toys and the job options. But girls, right from when they are born, are told by the men in their families that this is what you're going to be. But finally, it removes the choice to leave relationships, to leave families, to leave marriages. Because even saying that you don't enjoy being a mother is something that's shocking. Oh, what? Did you just say that? You're not even allowed to talk about it, right? When you're told, when you say it, when you can't complain about the housework you're doing, you can't express your opinions, but you also can't leave a relationship. You have to stay for the children. You have to stay to care for them. You have to stay because it's your role to protect your child. It undermines the choice to get a divorce. When you're constantly told, what will happen to your child? What will happen to that boy that's in your house? Remember, glorification uniquely hurts women and little girls. And in respect to what kinds of other pressures exist on women, this is something that is intrinsically problematic, something that we always forget and reject. Before I move on, yes? The expectation to have children is always going to exist for women. How is it easier for women to deal with this expectation when we are all constantly told that motherhood is not rewarding for them and we are the negative? So let's just rephrase that. They're saying, oh there are other things that contribute to this precious wealth. Then why do we need to remove one of the biggest contributors to it? But the other thing that they're saying in their POI is, oh we'll oppress you. But you should feel good about it. That you shouldn't complain about it. That you shouldn't get to, that movement shouldn't get to organize against it. Because when a feminist woman questions that, they're questioning something that's so important, so culturally relevant, we reject that. Second, glorification of a mother's sacrifices comes at the cost of her dreams. What is the cost of modernity?
First, a financial and a career trade-off. When you're not allowed to work. When you have to quit a career

because you're expecting a child. When you're not allowed to get into a higher study level, pursue a tertiary education for this. But why does this come from motherhood? Because you're raised with this expectation. When parental, societal, opposition's judgment extends to women who choose to prioritize themselves, you can't do what you've always dreamed of. We lose these scientists, these economists, these accountants. But also, you lose financial independence, right? You lose the mobility to leave a motherhood that you've entered at the point which you didn't have a job, at the point which you don't have your own personal savings. You're entirely reliant on the family. But there are many women who choose not to do this, who would rather choose not to do this. Opposition always forces them into this. Insofar as we save just those women, it's intensely regrettable. But even if sexism always places the pressure to have a child, what else does this concept of motherhood extend to? It extends to not being allowed to have your own hobbies, your own social life. But in that life, it's, oh, my friends are my child's friends' mothers. But I can't do the kinds of hobbies that I like, because I need to concentrate on my child's hobbies. Even if it's about women who are always going to end up in these marriages with these same children, they are still women who don't get to have their own lives, their own experiences, and in the least some mobility and some savings to live. But the extension of this is the external pressure, right? The external pressure that results in men getting a lesser burden in families. It's saying, oh, women are mothers so men are fathers. They can do things like taking care of their money. They can do things like taking care of careers. And it's based on disproportionate burdens on women. They have to take care of the dishes. Even if motherhood is enriching, it becomes not enriching at the point where they don't get the support of others because it's just their burden. The belief that women have to get meaning from their motherhood gives birth to an egregious body that you didn't check. 8 minutes 14 seconds. I would like to thank the first speaker of the proposition for their speech

and would like to invite the second speaker of the opposition to deliver their speech. Honourable panel, all of us believe that our mothers are the strongest, the most capable, the most hard-working people in the world.

We appreciate our mothers, and we believe that since they are mothers, they have assigned some positive attributes that they wouldn't have otherwise got unless they had became mothers. Then motherhood gave them these positive attributes of being a hard-working person, of being able to self-sacrifice and get out of your comfort zone to prioritize and take care of me as a child, for example.

We don't believe that motherhood and motherhood as a rewarding experience for personal development should be something that should be regretted. So firstly in my speech I'm going to talk about an engaged side propositions case and show how they're debating not the rewarding appreciation motion but rather a glorification, rather a due motion, then clarifying this debate up and then talking about my construction material, the most important things in this debate, which is firstly, how women's societal position is actually much better under our side when mothers are appreciated for doing what they do, and secondly, how we get better parenting and how we get better parents and better feeling parents overall, who appreciate what they're doing.

But now firstly, let's clear up this debate. What does exactly rewarding mean? It means that a parent, that a mother, is getting some positive benefits out of motherhood. For example, feeling good, getting love in the future from their baby, or feeling that their baby is giving them some positive emotions, or that they're getting some personal development out of it, but this is an experience that helps them to grow and be a better person. This debate, however, is not about the way the psychoposition wants to characterize it and say that females, whether females should be suppressed by society and should be denied the ability to not have a baby and should be denied the ability to get information or education, because obviously we oppose that too. Obviously we believe that females should be able to do whatever they like,

but what this debate actually means is that when you decide to have a baby, when you decide that motherhood is good, then we should rather perceive it as an enriching experience, as rather a rewarding experience to you as a society. So now, what did sarcopoposition say? That this is never rewarding and that glorification harms women and pressurises them to become mothers since it basically makes the duty to have children better. Not to steer a battle. That they never actually explain why perceiving mothers as having an enriching experience means that this duty is going away, or why this duty is made stronger by enriching experience. They never say how, but when we start to perceive motherhood as something negative or neutral, how then this duty is just abolishing. We're going to show you that this duty still exists and that this debate takes into the context whether we should reward these mothers for fulfilling that duty or whether we're not rewarding them. Why does this duty still exist and why this type of position to fail to provide another explanation? Firstly, women will be and are always the persons who are the only ones physically capable of carrying a child, so hence that duty will still exist under their shoulders, not under the male shoulders, they are the only ones physically capable of carrying a child. So hence that duty will still exist under their shoulders, not under the male's shoulders. They are the ones giving birth. And secondly, all societies, even the most liberal ones, are the ones to pressurise females still into having children and into bringing offspring to their nation. Even Germany pays mothers in order to have offspring to their nation. So this pressure still exists for these two reasons, and cyoposition never showed why this will cease to exist. So let's now talk about why rewarding mothers is good for societal level and secondly why it's better for parenting. First point, no thank you. Rewarding means that females' position in society will be better because the role still exists and we rather want to reward them and make them to see somebody that is not just fulfilling their burden that exists on their both sides, but rather somebody who is making that decision themselves, who are strong human beings, who make that decision because they believe that this is rewarding for them and they believe that they can gain some very personal benefits under that. Firstly, because you're not as strong if you're just as good in that duty, but rather we want to perceive females as doing that because they're doing it for themselves. And women are seen as not just doing their duty and being submissive, but rather wanting that baby and therefore deciding themselves to take that burden and to carry that baby. So, for example, New Zealand's Prime Minister just decided to have a baby in the office and we see it as a positive thing because she wanted to do it, because she feels that this would help her become a better person, help her become a happier person, a better Prime Minister for New Zealand, and we celebrate it. And therefore, the society feels that women are not just simply giving in to the pressure that society gives, but rather taking it because they want to. And this is something that we celebrate. Because, for example, in conscription service, this is a duty that, for example, in some states are for people. We celebrate that the person in health aversion becomes a better human being. And therefore we see that positive attributes are after doing that duty given to that person. And the same happens with women who happen to give birth, because they're seen as now better and more developed human beings. What are the impacts of this argument? Firstly, it means that females, when they break out of this duty to just live in, to be submissive, and rather be independent, strong women who make that decision themselves, are much more likely to be perceived as equal with men, because now they're not dependent on men and doing what men require, but rather doing what they themselves want. And so it makes the society perceive them as stronger, more capable, and hence policies that make their lives easier, such as, like, pay gap policies, or, for example, anti-discrimination policies, like the females are not accepted into the same jobs as men, or now, like, not as effective, because females are perceived as better, stronger, more equal with men, not having to do that duty, and rather, when they take that duty, it's something for the personal development, taking you in a second, so we expect it for the society if we see and perceive females as stronger themselves who want to do it, rather than just giving in to the pressure. Oh, is your point that somehow motherhood is appreciated more when it's seen as mothers doing it for their own self-interest? Yes. We believe that we want women to feel like they're doing something for their own self-interest rather than just giving in to some patriarchal policies. title: WSDC 2018 Round 3 - Bangladesh v Singapore
description: Rd 3 of the World Schools Debating Championships in Croatia. Bangladesh wins 3-0 vs Singapore on the motion: TH regrets the widespread belief that motherhood is a rewarding Experience.
motion: This house regrets the narrative that motherhood is a rewarding experience.

argument_units.text: I now invite the first speaker of cyber position to deliver their speech inside of the chamber. For far too long, I have been deceived by women to believe in the utopia of motherhood. That the sacrifices they make are minuscule to the rewards that they will generate. Where does this belief come from? It comes from the narrative that motherhood is a holy process, a process that can do you no harm. We change that from team proposition. Three burdens in our case.

First, why this narrative is false in the majority of cases. Second, why this narrative is false in the majority of cases. Second, why this narrative is coercive and harmful to women. And finally, how this narrative is harmful to the children these women bear. What does our world look like? Our world looks like that if you as a mother or an expectant mother want to find intrinsic value in the small things like your child walking or your child speaking his first words, then we are perfectly okay with that. We are not okay with you being coerced into believing that those minuscule moments of happiness cancel out every single sacrifice you make along the way for that to happen. Three arguments in my speech. First, why the narrative is false. Second, why this narrative is forced. And finally, the lasting effect it has on the child. Before I move on to Sher. Telling people that social work is rewarding equally causes them to become social workers. Do you therefore oppose this narrative? Yeah, sure. If any narrative goes absolutely unopposed in society and becomes something that you cannot oppose or cannot opt out of, then sure, we're happy to oppose that narrative as well, or find counter-narratives thereof.
First argument, why the narrative is false.

Because we understand that looking at your child succeed, or his first steps, can bring you happiness. But that's not the debate, whether you can garner small moments of happiness from your child. This debate is about whether that happiness weighs up in comparison to every single sacrifice that you make along the way. Because when is something rewarding? Something is only rewarding when the output or the outcomes of that action outweigh the efforts or the sacrifices that you make along the way. What do these sacrifices look like? First, the physical sacrifices. Now take it back. You as an expectant mother go through nine months of the worst hell that you'll ever experience in your entire life. You wake up every morning feeling nauseous, feeling the need to vomit, not only your food but also your blood. You feel like your food habits and what you want to do, where you want to go, what you want to see, all of these are being deeply affected and deeply changed by the concept of that pregnancy. You spend sleepless nights because your body's hormones have gone haywire and you literally cannot function throughout the entire day because you are exhausted, because your body feels like a bag of bones and flesh and not a functioning human body. In labor, you're going through the most painful experience known to man. A human woman's cervix will expand nine times its regular size when you're giving birth.
Imagine that amount of pain, that amount of excruciating pain,

not for an instant, but for 14 hours, for days, for days, in the cases of longer labors. Imagine all of that pain happening to you, and you simply believing that it doesn't happen. But the pain is also psychological, because this is a unique experience. We as men, or we as husbands and sons, cannot relate to what our mothers go through, our sisters go through when they are going through this pain. We cannot relate, we cannot console them in any effective manner whatsoever. These people psychologically when they are giving birth, when they are bearing children feel weak and feeble. Feel like they are victims to their circumstances and there is nothing that they can do about them. No medicine will comfort them as much as they want to. But finally, the harms are also to your identity. So even after that child has been born, you are forced to give up all of your identities in favor of motherhood. You lose out on your careers because your identity as a businesswoman or your identity as a politician comes inside your family, comes secondary to your identity and your responsibilities as a business woman or your identity as a politician comes inside your family, comes secondary to your identity and your responsibilities as a mother. But then, why are the rewards that you gain not sufficient? Because these harms are objective, but the rewards are, the harms that you incur are always objective, but the rewards are often subjective. The happiness that you gain from your child is not always rewarding. One, your child might not be successful but even if he is successful he might not follow exactly in your footsteps, grow up exactly how you imagined him to be. This child, but in the vast majority of cases, even if this child succeeds you have no ownership about that success because society tells you that these are all personal efforts of that child in and of itself. The conclusion of this is that the narrative that says that it is all worth bringing life into this world is simply false. Why is it bad to preach an incorrect narrative? Because the person that is making that decision is deceived into that narrative. This is the exact same reason why we don't allow things like false advertising or fake news. Because they establish a version of reality that is simply not true. But more importantly, this specific narrative is one that cannot be countered. Especially in developing countries where you are told that it's a requirement for women to have children. It's a responsibility of women to have children. This narrative is inescapable and thus it harms these women the most. Yes? The motion clearly calls for you to oppose motherhood as a whole. Do you not think it is convenient for you to just shrink your case to coercion? So, we don't think it calls for us to oppose motherhood as a whole. It calls for us to oppose the belief that motherhood is rewarding and only a rewarding experience. They cannot misconstrue the motion to their benefit. Second argument about why this narrative is coercive. What is coercion? Coercion is a form of manipulation that implicitly pressurizes you to do something. What are the tenets of coercion? Firstly, an informational asymmetry. Even when that information exists, that this isn't a rewarding experience, that is hidden from you by society, by means of that larger narrative, that this is rewarding. But secondly, also the lack of opt-out mechanism, why you cannot abandon that child. Even once you find out that this is not a rewarding experience, you cannot shirk your responsibilities. You can only embrace them further. Why is this coercion unique to all other forms of coercions that they will likely talk about in their case? One, the scale. Because compare this to the coercion that advertising or fake news chooses. Advertising coerces you into buying something. Fake news coerces you into voting for a certain party. This coercion literally coerces you to give up all your pre-existent identities and form a new identity. An identity which you do not understand the implications of. But secondly, also the effect. So other forms of coercion have a widespread effect and do not cater to you as an individual. But this is an individual, this
affects you on an individual scale where you're forcing every moment, every waking moment to buy into that narrative. How does this coercion work? From the very moment that child gets her first

period, that is a cause for celebration. Because that child is now ready to bear women. Your parents, your colleagues, your co-workers, all of them tell you that being a woman is an amazing thing. It's a glorious thing. And all of these harms are minuscule compared to that. Art and media tell you that the holy grail of womanhood is motherhood. That all of your identity has to be tied to that one single thing. What are the impacts of this? This impacts you in a couple of different ways. Because your entire identity being hinged on motherhood tells you that motherhood is all you need to be happy. So it's okay to give up that six-figure salary job. It's okay to give up that European vacation. Because you know what? You're a mother. And being a mother is all that will garner you happiness. But more importantly, you're also pushed on more responsibility because if something is rewarding, you have to work for that reward. So if the rewards are greater, your responsibility is greater. This is the way in which society tells you that it's the responsibility of women to look after their children. It's the responsibility of women to ensure that their children are brought up. And this narrative is a key component of that. We think that motherhood is great, but it's not as great as society will tend to inflame it to be.

and I would like to invite the first speaker of the opposition to deliver their speech. Members of the House, in society today, we tell males that every job they do is rewarding. We tell young boys that it is rewarding for them to aspire to be soldiers, doctors, lawyers. And we tell them to pursue their dreams. membuat mereka berani menjadi seorang peguam, doktor, peguam dan kita beritahu mereka untuk mengejar impian mereka. Kami berfikir ini adalah tingkatan patriarki untuk memberitahu ibu bapa bahawa perkara yang mereka lakukan di rumah, seperti menjaga anak mereka, mengajar mereka, memasak untuk mereka, tidak sama-sama berharga, hanya kerana mereka adalah wanita. Itulah yang kami menentang. Apa yang kami mula?

Pertama, kami tidak menyesal dengan percayaan yang luas bahawa keadaan ibu bapa adalah pengalaman yang menyenangkan. That's what we oppose. What's our stance? First, we do not regret the widespread belief that motherhood is a rewarding experience. Second, this obviously does not mean we have to stand for false or false experiences of motherhood, such as for instance when a woman is raped. Hence, this debate is clearly about instances where women choose to engage in motherhood. So to be clear, this debate falls under the category of third-wave feminism, where we recognise women's choices and everything that they are agen-ted should always be respected. Next, this does not mean we cannot stand for other empowering narratives, such as for example, women choosing to pursue a career in the workplace, we can also stand for fatherhood being an easily rewarding experience. No thank you. The role we envision is one where motherhood is valued by society, as is the case with any other profession. And this means that we are more likely to have things such as pensions deemed for an elderly woman, or paying housewives for their work.

What's our case ambition? First, I'll be proving to you how outside can empower mothers. Second, how we change societal attitudes towards women. kedua, bagaimana kita mengubah sifat sosial terhadap wanita, dan kedua, saya akan membincangkan bagaimana di luar mencipta lebih banyak keadilan dalam tanggungjawab rumah. Tetapi sebelum itu, beberapa pertanyaan terhadap kes mereka. Pertama, saya akan mengambil alasan pertama mereka tentang naratif palsu dan kedua, saya akan membuktikan mengapa keadilan ibu tidak kohesif. Tetapi sebelum itu, kita hanya perlu perhatikan bahawa kes mereka sudah berkurangan, walaupun sebelum saya mempertanyakan kerana mereka mengatakan bahawa pertemuan ini hanya berkaitan dengan keputusan yang akan dihukum. Kami telah memberitahu anda dengan jelas bahawa pertemuan ini perlu berkaitan dengan semua keputusan. Dan sisi mereka juga mempertahankan kebanyakan yang dihukum dalam pertemuan ini, bukan hanya keputusan yang dihukum. Dan saya akan membuktikan mengapa kebanyakan keadaan tidak dihukum dan mereka membuat keputusan dan kita harus memperbaikinya. Pada sub-sentensi pertama, ia adalah naratif palsu. Mari kita tahu bahawa mereka mengambil keuntungan, tetapi mereka hanya mengatakan bahawa ada keadaan kesakitan yang berlaku. Dua jawapan. Mari kita tahu bahawa mereka menggoda tentang makanan tidak berfungsi. Kerana saya rasa kesakitan ibu bapa sama-sama subjektif untuk semua orang, walaupun kita adalah makanan atau tidak. Jadi saya hanya mengeluarkan naratif ini dari pendapat ini. Kedua, mereka mengatakan perbezaan antara kesalahan objektif dan kesalahan subjektif, bahawa beberapa keuntungan adalah objektif atau kesalahan adalah subjektif. Mari kita tahu bahawa segalanya dalam keadaan ibu, ialah subjektif seperti kesalahan yang ibu menderita, kegembiraan yang ibu menderita, semua ialah subjektif. Jadi siapa yang akan diadjudikasi, apakah itu menyenangkan atau tidak? Saya rasa metrik untuk adjudikasi adalah pilihan dan anda fikir not? I think that the metric for adjudication is to be choice, and you think that the choice is something that outside empowers. Let's then move on to the last random idea of identity. I think that if anything, having a rewarding narrative is what empowers women even more. I will show you later why this rewarding narrative is what empowers women in the workplace as well, something that their side wanted to talk about. On the idea of coercion, we think that outside breaks the idea of coercion because we think there are competing narratives on our side of the house as well. So we think that women can make a fair and balanced choice in regards to whether or not they think the choice of parenthood is clear. No thank you. So I think that this is basically the case dealt with.

My first substantive will show you how we empower women. The thesis of this argument is that women who choose to be mothers should not be told that they are oppressing themselves. We start from a very basic premise that motherhood is something that a sizeable number of women are going to engage in. We obviously do not live in a world with artificial wombs or one where males can take on the biological function of giving birth to a child. So for society to function, we do need offspring, and we think that only women can do this. In fact, I think it is uniquely empowering to be a woman, to be able to carry on your legacy, to be able to contribute to the future of humanity by giving birth to the next generation of people. So why is the narrative that motherhood is rewarding and empowering for these women? Because we believe that it is wrong to tell these women that they are oppressing themselves. If anything, I think this narrative stands on a very patriarchal notion that the value of the world is based on what men do. So if their side sees this coercive, I think their side encranges this coercion even more. Think about it. A mother's process of teaching their children, pouring their hearts and souls into the child's upbringing is inherently valuable. When a mother goes through children's fairy tales and Aesop's fables, instilling moral values, no doubt, into a daughter, till the day she comes home with a police force job acceptance letter in her hands. When a mother nurtures social interaction skills into a son, till the day she sees him walking down the aisle, happily married. So who is Tim Blankenash to say that all of these emotional fruits of labour are always inferior to capitalist pursuits? For one observer, hence we think that we recognise that the fruits of motherhood is empowering. But before I move on, Sean. In a world where these successes of the children don't exist, what do you tell mothers around the world? We think that you can debate only a small extent of this debate when the children become unsuccessful. The point of sight of Team Singapore is very clear. We think that when mothers engage in parenthood, they recognise that there's a spectrum of outcomes that might occur to a child. But regardless, the choice that they make is empowering. They need to do it with this entire spectrum, not just the cases where the child goes wrong. dan keadaan yang mungkin akan berlaku kepada anak-anak. Tetapi tidak kira-kira pilihan yang mereka buat adalah memperoleh. Mereka perlu melakukan dengan sepanjang jenis, bukan hanya kes-kes di mana anak-anak berjalan dengan salah. Jika ada apa-apa, saya akan mengambil alasan dan mengatakan bahawa walaupun anak-anak tidak menjadi SDIU atau SDIU atau menjadi penyakit, itu tidak bermakna idea keadaan ibu-ibu secara keseluruhan ini tidak berharga. Kerana ibu-ibu sendiri yang membuat pilihan dengan pengakuan ini. Tetapi kita harus tahu bahawa idea kepercayaan hanya berdiri di sisi mereka. themselves made the choice with this recognition. But let's just note that the idea of disempowerment only stands on their side, because it stands on the male narrative that only office work is valuable. So the point here is this. title: WSDC 2019 Round 3 — Greece vs. Singapore
description:
Round 3 of the 2019 WSDC, with Greece on Prop and Singapore on Opp.

The motion was: In art and popular culture, THBT creating new lead characters for minorities (e.g. Hancock, Black Panther) is better than recasting existing roles already played by other actors/communities (e.g. Ghostbusters, The Little Mermaid).

Singapore won on a 3-0 decision.
motion: This house prefers creating new lead characters for minorities over recasting minorities in pre-existing roles.

argument_units.text: From Black Panther to Moana to Jedi Ray, roles written to be played by minorities uniquely represent their experience, empowering minority viewers and avoiding backlash. We don't want a world where existing roles pretend to be representative by adding a sprinkle of minorities just in the actors that play them, because we on Proposition believe that minorities are more than just different characteristics like skin color and gender. They're about different stories.
Three points in opposition today. Firstly, on empowering minorities. Secondly, on public perception. And in my partner's speech, thirdly, on minority actors.

Before that, let's define the notion. By art and popular culture, we're talking about movies, TV shows, theatre, musicals, everything, right? Secondly, by minorities, we're talking about racial, ethnic, religious, sexual orientation minorities. And we would also include women because of the societal oppression they face. Thirdly, by moving characters... Is this a clarification? Yes. Okay, sure.
Do you think that a misogynistic character should continue being portrayed as misogynistic?

I don't think this is affected by the notion in any way. Presumably, this would be the same on both sides. If you want to clarify the next speech, you should do so. new characters returning. We think the criteria for this debate should be, when do we support a movement regarding diversity in popular culture? This argument will prove that meaningful representation only comes when you see someone like you having their own story and character and not just having the same skin colors. title: WSDC 2023 Round 4 - Malaysia vs Sri Lanka
description:
Vietnam World Schools Debating Championship 2023 Round 4

Motion: This house believes that the feminist movement should promote the maximisation of individual development and empowerment over solidarity among women

Proposition: Malaysia  
Opposition: Sri Lanka  

Results: Opposition won.

Disclaimer: The speakers were assigned a topic and a speaking position. Their speeches do not reflect their own personal views or opinions.

#WSDC2023 #MWS2023 #TeamMalaysia2023 #WSDC #debate
motion: This house believes that the feminist movement should prioritize individual choice over collective solidarity.

argument_units.text: The need for solidarity within the feminist movement has expired, and what remains of it is but a mere veneer for the condemnation of the most vulnerable women by the upper echelon standard in society. Proposition is the style that stands for all women and for that reason we're so proud to propose. Before I forward two substantive arguments within this speech, onto our set of big things. Firstly, what does a world where the feminist movement promote the maximization of individuals look like? We think it is one where we prioritize things like choice feminism. So there are two main defining characteristics underneath this. One, individuals in every aspect of society are left to decide what is best for them. So for instance, when it comes to social interactions, we'd be perfectly fine with women weaponizing the patriarchy for their own benefit. Or when it comes to things like economic enfranchisement, we will also be fine with women cursing a job promotion, even if it comes at the expense of another woman. Secondly, there's respect for the individual choices that individuals make. So for example, when our political opinions divulge, that is acceptable, we don't need to condemn women for it. Secondly, what is the nature of the feminist movement in the status quo? Three things. One, I'd like to point out the feminist movement is experiencing an unprecedented level of power in the status quo as a result of all-time awareness regarding necessity for things like gender equality. But two, not that many of the things that are fundamental for basic living standards, for example, marriage equality and voting rights, have already been achieved in the status quo, so there isn't as much as a need for solidarity as opposition may point out. Lastly, the biggest hurdles that the feminist movement experiences now are no longer collective systems of oppression, but rather individualistic, and we only think it's under a paradigm where we empower individual empowerment, where that can be dealt with.

Lastly, not that this debate isn't about the instances where what is good for the individual and the collective alliance, because on either side that would be symmetric. What we need to focus on is that when individual empowerment is perceived to come at the expense of solidarity, that is where the trade-off happens on the side of opposition. Two arguments can be reached. Firstly, a principle on how the maximization of individual empowerment best deals with the diverse circumstances of women, and secondly, why individual empowerment overcomes the hurdles to a success that women face. Only first argument, three parts. First of all, not that the patriarchy's enforcement of oppression is varying, so I'd just like to preface this argument by saying that gone are the days where all women are affected in the same way by coercive structures. Why is this the case? We think it's because the patriarchy's imposition of oppression is no longer universal but in fact it's subjective. To illustrate, for example, women who are conventionally attractive in the status quo are treated as sexual objects by men, but the same women who might not fit the norms of conventional beauty aren't able to enjoy things like pretty privilege. So what this shows is that social expectations have evolved to the point where oppression is individualised, and we think the best way to combat it is to allow individuals to pursue the avenues of empowerment that they deem are most suited for their circumstances. Secondly, we think solidarity on their side, as espoused by the feminist movement, merely extends the oppression that women face. Why is this the case? Well, in order for them to have things like collective solidarity, three things happen. Firstly, all women are presumed to have to operate on a collective in order to save individuals who might not know what is best for them. So what you do essentially is that you homogenise what is best for all women. So for example, a woman who chooses to don the hijab is considered to be oppressed, and individuals who might opt into things like sex work by her only fans are perceived to not want to do it. It's merely coercive. Why is this problematic? Secondly, they would institute policies that come at the expense of other women. So for example, the justification for banning things like the hijab is that it's anti-feminist and that all women are actually coerced into wearing it. The problem here that we want to highlight is that more often than not, the most privileged women who are often white and wealthy get to dictate what is best for all women because what is inherently tied to the notion of solidarity is that it entrenches a savior complex. Finally, in order to do things like maintain solidarity, there's a necessity to demonize any women who don't fit into what the collective ought to do. So you on the side of opposition want to push everyone into the same agenda in order to deter individuals who might want to opt out of it, need to do things like demonize any anomalies and that is seen exactly on the side of opposition when the movement does things like stigmatize sex workers by saying that they are coerced into it and they don't actually want to do it. It's extremely discriminatory towards them. Finally, not only the purpose of the feminist movement is to empower individuals, and insofar as the first two parts of the argument have proven that they cannot get that change that is tailored to the individual, their world actually fails women. What happens on our side when we do things that prioritize agency? One, individuals aren't shamed for pursuing things that divulge from what the collective ought to know. But secondly, because we think that individuals are the best arbiters at ascertaining what is the best form of empowerment for themselves, they are more likely going to access it on their side, compared to those when they have to compromise, and some women are inevitably going to get traded off on their side. But before I go on to the second argument, sure.
In a world where pretty privilege and

high beauty standards exist together, isn't it better for women that have pretty privilege not to exploit it to the detriment of others, and for women that cannot meet high beauty standards to have greater solidarity with those women that do conform and fight patriarchal norms together? So the issue with that is, one, you would have to force women who might not necessarily want to self-sacrifice to sacrifice on your side.

So you think that's why you're going to garner resentment within the movement. But secondly, more importantly, you think it it's far better because when at least some women can exploit their pretty privilege, get into positions of power where they actually have the force to do things like change on-the-ground policies, there's a better capacity to help women who might not necessarily benefit from things like pretty privilege.

On to the second argument explaining why individual empowerment overcomes the hurdle to a success that women face in the status quo. Firstly, I'd like to characterize the political status of the feminist movement in the status quo. So although it may be controversial to consider yourself a feminist, we have already amassed enough numbers in doing things like voting legislation into effect, garnering baseline protection for women. So what this shows is that any critical mass that opposition wants to talk about that is only achieved via solidarity is no longer necessary for the feminist movement. What we need to do instead is to combat how stereotypes that manifest on a case-by-case basis, which a narrative of solidarity uniquely cannot cater to, because you aren't focusing on the individual, you make all women focus on one thing. Secondly, look at all the labels that incapacitate women are actually combated under our narrative. And I'd like to highlight something here, which is that individual empowerment under a capitalistic system, which exists on both sides of the house, by the way, will always come at the expense of someone else because resources are zero-sum and someone will always have to lose out. So we don't care if the structure is contributing to stereotypes. What we uniquely prove is how our narrative can deal with these stereotypes, but they can't. How are women empowered on our side? Three things. One, when we don't shame women from prioritising individual upliftment, we think that is when they're more willing to accept things like job promotions, without feeling a sense of guilt that the feminist movement says that you have deprived another woman of that opportunity. Shame on you. But suddenly, traits associated with men no longer become exclusive to men only when women are also able to ascend to positions of power. So for example, a woman is no longer considered bossy. She can also be considered a leader when she is the CEO of a company. But thirdly, for those in the most vulnerable positions in society, what we tell these individuals is that the only obligation they owe is to them themselves and they don't need to sacrifice more in order to be considered a good feminist. What we tell these individuals is that the only obligation they owe is to them themselves and they don't need to sacrifice more in order to be considered a good feminist. Here is the comparative that opposition will have to defend. We think their rate of progress is actually far slower. Why? Three reasons. One, whenever a woman has the opportunity to ascend the corporate ladder on their side, the movement tells her she should wait because if she accepts this promotion, she deprives another woman of that opportunity. So certainly, on that, we think there's less ascension to power because resources are spent on attempting to uplift everyone and their inevitably rationed on their side. Lastly, in their best case, when there are women who land into powerful positions, you don't spotlight these individuals because their participation contributes to oppression. Finally, we think opposition forwards an extremely damaging perception of the movement, that we are all the same, we have to fight for the same thing, but we don't suffer from this because our narrative is one that's focused on how all individuals deserve the ability to individually empower themselves.
